PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmania Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and the Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate Inquiry into South West Tasmania. A Federal Inquiry has been recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
1. planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin
2. closing country telegraph offices
3. increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service
4. withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices
5. generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30% of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bolkus (from 23 citizens) and Button (from 137 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens of Australia
concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown;
convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and
believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened
humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to
1. Reject any moves towards divorce by post
2. Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage
3. Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
4. Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
5. Encourage counselling towards reconciliation
6. Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
(i) intolerable behaviour;
(ii) desertion for two years;
(iii) separation for three years.
and we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Coates (from 18 citizens), Robert Ray (from 21 citizens) and Walsh ( from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Quality of Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that some television stations throughout Australia are taking advantage of the absence of ratings surveys during the Christmas-New Year holiday season to broadcast inferior quality programs and innumerable repeats.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will undertake and publish the results of ratings surveys during holiday periods to encourage the broadcasting of quality TV programs at those times.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister Mr Anthony M.P.

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75% and that at 1.9.82 the amount of principal had only been reduced by $395.06, since 1.10.1981 leaving a balance of $14,609.94.

(2) Your Petitioners therefore request that the Government immediately make available similar generous terms to the many thousands of home buyers in Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to abnormally high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Multicultural Broadcasting
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The successive promises of the Federal Government to introduce ethnic television into Australia have only been carried out in respect to Sydney and Melbourne, ignoring other centres with large ethnic populations such as Adelaide .
2. The large proportion of the population of Adelaide is denied certain cultural rights including the viewing of television programmes broadcast in languages other than English.

3. The enormous benefits which arise from ethnic television in a multicultural society such as Australia, especially in respect to the exchange of ideas and exposing people to different views and cultures.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will request the Government to extend the operations of the Special Broadcasting Service's television service, Channel 0/28, to Adelaide without delay.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tax Avoidance and Evasion
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That the continuing high level of tax avoidance and evasion is cause for grave concern for honest Australian taxpayers, and demands stringent and immediate action by the Commonwealth, noting in particular:
1. The latest estimate by the Australian Taxpayers' Association is that $7,000m a year is being lost in taxation revenue;
2. This figure can only continue to rise because of the timid approach by the Government in closing off tax loopholes; and
3. No effective inroads can be made until a comprehensive policy is adopted of levying tax from the date on which a scheme of tax avoidance is first used.

Senator McLaren-Mr President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is that the description of the petition that I presented is not correct. The term ' young couples' is not mentioned in the petition. I mentioned this last week. I ask that that error be rectified in relation to any future petitions that I present.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bolkus (from 19 citizens) and Robert Ray (from 9 citizens).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate-

(a) a user-pay principle should be instituted by which the manufacturers, sellers and users of substances which can be demonstrated to cause increased costs of health care to the community, should contribute substantially towards that cost.
(b) the Government should institute a health cost compensating tax which would be applied to the following:
(i) Tobacco products
(ii) Alcohol products
(iii) Products containing excessive amounts of sugar, salt, or other harmful additives.

(c) a special committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council should be established to assess, on a conservative basis, the minimum health care costs caused by a product, to provide a basis on which the tax should be assessed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of conflicting terminology which is being used, is the Government proposing to introduce a wages freeze or a wages pause? Which is it to be and what is to be its duration? Will there be provision for a catch-up at the end of the period of freeze or pause?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has made it abundantly clear that it seeks, throughout Australia, to get for a period of a year a cessation of the upward movement of wages. It has made that abundantly clear. Whether one wants to use the word 'freeze' or whether one wants to use the word 'pause', the fact is that what the Government aims to do is to bring about stability of the wage system over a period of a year. Quite clearly, the aim is to bring about a reduction, a dramatic reduction if possible, in inflation and, at the same time, to stop the shedding of labour by industries because of high costs. We hope that , by reducing the costs of industries, they will not only maintain their present work force but also in fact increase their work force. The aim, as Senator Button well knows, is to use the money saved in this regard by governments and by enterprise for creating jobs, new employment. The whole question of what should happen at the end of the pause is, of course, a very sensitive one. If indeed there were a sudden upsurge in inflation that could destroy much of the value of the pause. That is a matter which, no doubt, will be the subject of discussion at the Premiers Conference level. The Government needs the co- operation of the Premiers and it needs the co-operation of commerce and industry . Those discussions are currently taking place.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister' s answer, I ask him whether he has seen the statement by Mr Powell of the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures, as reported in yesterday's Press, that ' guaranteeing a rise' at the end of a wage pause would be 'in the best interests of industrial relations and stability'. Did Mr Powell say that the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures also thought that a six months pause was long enough with inflation running at 12 per cent or more? Does the Government agree that there should be a guaranteed wage rise, as advocated by Mr Powell, at the end of any pause?

—Before I call upon the Leader of the Government in the Senate to answer that question, I suggest to honourable senators that they should be careful to ensure that any supplementary question they ask is in fact a supplementary question. From the chair I observe that that question was more in the nature of another question than supplementary to the first question. I merely mention that. I do not wish points of order to be taken. I call on the Leader to answer Senator Button's question, if he wishes.

—Mr President, I do not wish to canvass your ruling on that matter, although I would very much like to do so at a later stage. With respect, given the Minister's answer to my first question, it was clearly a supplementary question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see the statement. I am aware that certain persons are advocating a six months wage pause rather than a one year wage pause . The Government takes the view that it would need a longer period to get true stability and to get the factors that would be conducive to re-employment. As to the question of what happens at the end of the freeze or pause, I have pointed out that this is a matter for delicate negotiation because if there were a very substantial rise it would re-institute a stimulus to inflation and so--
—Rubbish! It is a matter for government policy. You know that.
—This is a supplementary interjection to a supplementary question.
—It is all rubbish you are talking.

—Senator Button can afford to be irritated at this moment because the Australian Labor Party is finding itself more and more isolated in its stance. It is finding now that the Australian Council of Trade Unions is seeing sense in stability of wages at this moment. One by one people are falling away from the Labor Party's stance. Senator Button is left with his own irritation and his own realisation that the stance that he has led his party into is as wrong as can be and is not supported by the people of Australia. I leave him to his irritation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to the decision of the Queensland Government to pipe oil from the Jackson field to Brisbane. This would mean the construction of a 770- kilometre pipeline from Jackson to Moonie, probably at a cost of about $125m, in lieu of a pipeline from Jackson to Moomba of 150 kilometres at a cost of about $ 30m, whence the oil would travel the just completed pipeline to the Stoney Point fractionation plant. Is it in the nation's best interests that this extra $95m be expended, or does the Minister still hold the view he put to Estimates Committee E in September that the better economics would be to link the field to the Cooper Basin field?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think at the Estimates Committee I pointed out that this was fundamentally a matter upon which the individual States and the individual enterprises would make their decisions. It is one thing to look at economics. I am sure that it is cheaper, as Senator Hill said, to link the Jackson field with the general Cooper Basin pipeline. There is no doubt about that at all. Other matters may have a bearing, including the intentions and the decisions of the Queensland Government with respect to the developing of oil and gas fields and refineries. I would need more information on those matters before I made any judgment. My understanding is that some discussions are likely to take place with my Department and me. Really until that happens I think I had better not adjudicate on the fairly simplistic information before me at the moment. Of course, it must be cheaper to run a pipeline to the Moomba link and to connect there. That must be so. I would need to know more about some other factors before I adjudicated any further.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. In the terminology that I use I am assuming that a freeze means a period of no wages increase, with no catch-up at the end of it, and that a pause is a period without a wages increase but with a catch-up at the end of it. If the Government has other ideas about those terms, I hope Senator Chaney will define them. When can we expect a definitive statement of Government policy on whether or not there will be a catch-up at the end of the wage freeze period? Will the Minister tell us whether the Government is proposing a freeze or a pause in the public sector only or in both the public and private sectors? If the latter is proposed, how will a freeze or pause be applied in the private sector?

—The precise meaning of the terminology mentioned by Senator Walsh has been the subject of some discussions in the media as well as in this place. Clearly, if what the Government was proposing was something which permitted a catch-up at the end of whatever period was involved, whether it be six or 12 months, there would be no change after that time in Australia's competitive position. So, if the concern of the Government, among other objectives, is to improve Australia's competitive position, the question of a catch-up becomes one of real difficulty. Since I have been asked for a definitive reply, I will ask my colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to give it to me.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. The Minister, inadvertently or otherwise, has not replied at all to the latter half of my question. Will the proposed freeze or pause apply in the public sector only or in both the public and private sectors? If the latter is proposed, how does the Government intend to apply a freeze or pause in the private sector?

—I think it has been made quite clear that the objective of the Government would be to obtain a freeze in both the public and the private sectors. The precise means by which that will be brought about is a matter which will have to follow the Premiers Conference next Tuesday, when we will be seeking the co-operation of all the relevant governments of Australia in pursuing that very laudable objective.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. Is it a fact that the Freedom of Information Act comes into effect tomorrow, 1 December? Is this legislation a strong example of the present Government's commitment to open government as expressed in the words of the Prime Minister that if Australian electors are to be able to make valid judgments on Government policy they should have the greatest possible access to information? Are all governments ready to make the Act effective as from tomorrow?

—The answer to the first of the questions asked is yes, the Act does come into operation tomorrow. The answer to the second question is yes, it is a strong example of the Government's commitment to open government. The answer to the third question is yes, a good deal of effort has been made throughout departments. Although Senator Hamer asked whether governments were ready, I think he meant to ask whether government departments were ready to implement the Act. I can say that a great deal of preparation has been done in all departments. In my department, which is a very large department and which expects to have a very large volume of inquiries, several thousand officers have been given advice on the operation of the Act. It is certainly the hope of the Government that the operation will commence smoothly tomorrow.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment a question concerning the failure of the Government to date to provide the vital background information to the World Heritage Committee for the nomination of South West Tasmania to the World Heritage List. Has the Minister indicated that this information, which includes even the actual delineation of the area to be nominated, has not yet been finalised and not yet forwarded to the Commission which meets in Paris on 13 December? Can the Minister explain why it was not forwarded when the nomination was lodged in June 1982? Does the Minister not find it strange that the Government has been unable to come to a decision to send the information when it has known of the nomination since November 1981 when the then Tasmanian Government passed on the nomination to the Federal Government? Can the Minister give an unconditional guarantee that the great length of time involved in getting this information will in no way jeopardise the hearing of South West Tasmania's nomination on 13 December next by the World Heritage Committee?

—I have an answer for Senator Chipp which I hope will reassure him considerably. The nomination of the South Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks to the World Heritage Committee was made by the Australian Government in December 1981 and the nomination then was supported with substantial information. On the basis of that nomination and that information the Bureau of the World Heritage Committee at its meeting in June 1982 unconditionally recommended for inscription on the World Heritage List the South West Tasmania nomination. In doing so the Bureau sought certain additional information. The World Heritage Committee has already placed the matter on the agenda for its meeting on 13 December 1982. It is on the agenda now. The information sought by the Bureau is presently being finalised and will be provided in time for the hearing. I repeat that the information will be available in time for the hearing. In order to support that hearing the permanent head of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment, Dr Don McMichael, has already left Australia to present Australia's case. He will be assisted by the Chairman of the Australian Heritage Commission, Mr Max Bourke. The Prime Minister has stated unequivocally that it is the Government's wish that the listing proceed. As I read the sequence of events, I have no reason to doubt that that will be possible.

—I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister responsible not know that today is 30 November? Does he not know that only 13 days remain between now and 13 December? Twenty-one different countries will be represented at that meeting in Paris and presumably the delegates to the conference will want to have some of this information before they leave their home countries in order to consult with their officials or whomever. Is it the Government's wish that the permanent head of the Department should present this information, including the actual delineation of the area, in a handout to the meeting of the Commission on the morning of 13 December?

—What I set out in my answer makes it clear that the nomination has been put forward in a way that has been endorsed already by the Bureau of the World Heritage Committee. The extra information will help. I believe that there is adequate information there for the listing to be considered and to proceed. Senator Chipp cannot make a crisis when no crisis exists. The information is being gathered. Dr McMichael has left for overseas, and the information will be available.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. On 21 September at a meeting of Senate Estimates Committee G I asked for a detailed breakdown of the Commonwealth's contribution to private hospitals in 1981-82. As more than two months has elapsed, I ask whether the Minister has any indication of when the information might be received by me.

—I remember the Estimates Committee G hearing and Senator Walters's interest in this matter. It is now two months ago. I agree that the honourable senator should have a response from the Department of Health. I shall try to expedite one for her. It is quite appropriate that she raises the matter again in the Senate now.

—My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations follows previous questions relating to the Government's wages policy. Is the Government committed to a decentralised wage fixation system based on collective bargaining? If so, how does it explain the fact that the proposed wages freeze is the most centralised system of wage fixation ever proposed in Australia?

—For some time the Government has been encouraging decentralised wage fixing arrangements. I think that already some evident success has flowed from that. But at the same time there have been considerable settlements which have given rise to wage pressures which we believe, and I think the Australian community believes, to have been utterly counter-productive. In those circumstances, and given the particular conditions which have emerged in Australia over recent months, I believe that most people would accept that extraordinary measures are called for. The seeking of this wage pause is an action of government which is clearly receiving widespread support. The sense of it is evident to the Australian community. It is about time the Opposition stopped trying to score points on the matter and got into the business of trying to assist Australia at a time of serious difficulty.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. It is about 'Sibyl'. I refer to reports that British Aerospace and Brandt Armaments of France have produced a fully automatic and 'intelligent'- whatever that might mean-missile decoy system for ships called 'Sibyl'. It consists of an above-deck multi-tube rocket launcher, decoy modes and fully automatic control system. Has the Department of Defence made any evaluation of ' Sibyl'? Is it a counter to all known anti-ship missile threats, including sea skimmers such as Exocet? If so, is any action being taken to procure this system for our warships?

—Yes, I understand that a system is being developed in France, known as 'Sibyl', and that it is broadly as described by Senator Lewis in his question. The Government does not have full information on the matter. Therefore , no detailed evaluation has yet been undertaken. However, the Government is being kept informed on all decoy systems of the kind outlined. Presently, Royal Australian Navy FFG class ships are fitted with United States Navy chaff launchers, known as superrapid blooming off-board chaff or SRBOC. There is a further system, I understand, in development in Australia. This is being undertaken by Australian scientists and was announced in April as being set up in the format of a hovering rocket decoy system, and consequently it may indeed fit the Navy requirements in due course. As I said, that system is under development at present and it may be some considerable time before it comes to pass. The system that is being developed in this country would be significantly different from 'Sibyl'. The evaluation that is finally undertaken would be a matter of very careful consideration by the Government at the appropriate time.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to statements made by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Macphee, that in conjunction with the proposed wages freeze or pause a prices monitoring or surveillance mechanism should be introduced. I ask: What system of prices surveillance or monitoring does the Government propose to introduce?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Premiers Conference will be the forum in which the Government will bring forward its suggestions. The Premiers will bring forward their suggestions on a whole range of matters including the wage freeze. No doubt there will be full discussions on the question of prices monitoring. I can understand the anxiety of members of the Australian Labor Party in wanting to know these things since the Labor Party is devoid of policies. I suggest they contain their anxiety until next Tuesday when the Commonwealth Government will be putting forward its policies.
—I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that notwithstanding Mr Macphee's series of public statements on the matter the Government has no policy on prices surveillance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I think you had cause today to remark that some supplementary questions bore no relationship at all to the previous question or answer. I did not say anything of the sort; Senator Evans invented a hypothetical question just for the sheer melodrama of his own fruity rhetoric. I said nothing of the sort. If he wants to give rise to fruity rhetoric he is entitled to do so.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. In view of the attitudes of the European Economic Community, in particular as expressed at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade conference, and the considerable downturn in sales of clothing, textiles and footwear items at the retail level-imports of these items were in brighter times fixed on quantitative levels and not market percentages-can the Minister advise whether any reconsideration is now contemplated or under way so that Australian manufacturers can at least be assured of the percentages of the market that they had at the time when quotas were applied?

—I cannot say that since the very recently announced EEC attitudes to which the question referred became public there has been any Government reconsideration of the matter. Clearly, the Government is concerned at the lack of progress in achieving its objectives at that international meeting and is disappointed at the attitudes adopted by the EEC which are seen by the Government as attitudes which are not in the interests of the world economy and certainly not in Australia's interests. With respect to the arrangements which apply to textiles, clothing and footwear, the fact is that under the arrangements which were announced some time ago for those industries the Government has established an advisory committee which is headed by an independent chairman. That committee is responsible for monitoring industry conditions and providing advice on any changes to the program which might be necessary to ensure that the Government's objectives are met. Recent discussions have been held by that committee. A report is expected to be with Ministers before the end of the year. No doubt the conditions in world trade and the attitudes which the EEC adopted at the recent meeting in Geneva will be matters which will affect Ministers' consideration of that report.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It refers to the proposed wages freeze or pause and in particular the proposed freeze on wages in the private sector for which, as I understand from a previous answer of Senator Chaney, no method of implementation has yet been determined. I ask: What guarantee will there be that any additional liquidity, which it is claimed will result to private employers, from such a freeze will not be used to replace capital equipment or increase profit margins rather than engage additional employees? Has it been determined how the Government will implement any such guarantee, if it is to be implemented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As far as the wages pause is concerned, a number of things will have to be discussed with the State governments at the meeting next week. It has already been stated that the Commonwealth Government's savings on Public Service salaries will be put to effect in creating employment opportunities, probably through both State programs and Commonwealth programs. That is the only position determined by the Commonwealth at this stage. If the States participate in the wages pause savings made through the Commonwealth sector will be directed to programs, some of which will be of a Commonwealth nature and some of which will be of State government origin. All these things have yet to be discussed with the States. It is a little early to expect definitive answers on matters that are to be the subject of consultation. If we were to go to the Premiers Conference having defined all these answers being requested today it would be pointless to have the consultation with the States that undoubtedly will occur next week.

ANSWER.PARA: I can understand that the Opposition wishes to determine its own policy because of some of the statements of the State Premiers and others in recent weeks-and even of some of the unions. As far as the Commonwealth Government is concerned, it has said a number of things quite precisely, including that it would hope to see a 12 months wages pause in the private sector and in the public sector and that the savings in the public sector would be directed towards assisting employment opportunities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked about the private sector; I didn't ask about the public sector at all. We have had five minutes from you on the public sector and nothing on the private sector.

— We hope the private sector can make savings, which will assist in profitability and the maintaining of employment levels. That is the outcome that I think we are seeking-the continuation of as many employment opportunities as possible. If the private sector is not able to achieve some moderation in wages, undoubtedly there will be continued unemployment and a reduction in employment opportunities for the future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer noted an article in the Australian on 29 November reporting that the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia uncovered a new set of statistics which shows the effect State government charges and taxation have in increasing inflation. It is further reported that the Leader of the Opposition stated:

QUESTION.PARA: It is clear from this analysis that efforts to fight inflation will be fruitless unless they bear down on State taxes and charges.

Can the Minister inform the Senate why the Australian Bureau of Statistics has not made that information public and has released it only to a selected person- the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia? Further, can the ABS be instructed to publish that information with each release of consumer price index figures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware that the information referred to by Senator Lajovic has not been announced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics . On the general matter of State government charges increasing inflation, undoubtedly all the things in the CPI measurement have an effect on inflation. We do have to look at whether the States and the Commonwealth are seeking cost recovery in the charges that they impose for their services. It is a little unrealistic to suggest that State government charges for services given should not reflect the costs of those services. As far as the general part of the question is concerned, in relation to the release of statistics to the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia, I am not aware of that. I do point out that government charges in many cases ought to reflect some objective of cost recovery.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Are the projected savings of $700m from the proposed wages freeze to be used for job creation schemes in the public construction area? Is the Minister able to give the Parliament any details of these schemes? If there has been room for a $700m boost to the public construction area with its attendant employment benefits, why has the Government not acted sooner, for example in respect of this year's Budget? What guarantees can the Minister give that the supposed savings from the wages freeze will be used for job creation purposes and not simply to reduce the Budget deficit, which is expanding rather alarmingly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am intrigued by the last phrase, that the Budget deficit is expanding rather alarmingly. It remains less than what the Australian Labor Party has advocated as being a respectable Budget deficit. Having said that--
—We asked you last week what a respectable deficit would be and you could not tell us.

—Mr President, I am sorry for the frustrations of the interjectors. The Government's aim is to obtain a wages freeze and, by saving in the Commonwealth Government sector, both in its own Public Service and in its statutory authorities, an amount of some $700m, to employ that money directly towards forms of public works which essentially will be labour-intensive in themselves but which, nevertheless, also will be of high priority. That money will be used entirely for those purposes. The important thing is that it will not be the creation of new money; it will be the recycling of existing money. It will not have--
—Somebody else's money.

—Yes, indeed it will be. It will take into account Mr Crean's famous phrase, which the Labor Party now rejects, that one man's pay increase is another man's job. We will continue to remind members of the Labor Party of that phrase. In other words, we will be helping to create employment by stopping the upper thrust of wages which has created the unemployment. That has been recognised. The fact is that had we done this in the Budget it would have been necessary to increase the deficit by another $700m. We were not willing to do so. We are willing to bear down on inflation and, at the same time, widen the opportunities for jobs. It is a sensible suggestion which, I remind the Senate, is now being accepted widely by at least two-thirds of the community and by a majority of supporters of all political parties. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of any dispute among Aboriginals over the distribution of Ranger royalties. ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the events which occurred are as follows: On 24 February $501 ,000 was paid from the ABTA to the Northern Land Council. I understand that recently $281,500 was paid to Chudleigh Pty Ltd, a company which is to be renamed Gagadju Holdings Pty Ltd. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. In the light of the severe and fast increasing extent of unemployment, can the Minister affirm that the Government no longer regards the vast majority of those out of work as dole bludgers? If this is so, can the Minister explain why the Government still discriminates against the unemployed by allowing them to earn only an additional $10 a week without a penalty, compared with $30 a week for a single person on the age pension? In view of the fact that there is a much larger number of family men now on the dole, I ask the Minister whether he seriously considers the necessities of life for a child-even the bare means of life-can be provided for $10 a week, that being the amount now paid. Will the Government actively consider improving the situation in both respects in the mini Budget which, without doubt, will be brought down early next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator asked a series of questions relating to unemployment and did not improve his questions by making the silly point he started off with about referring to certain people as dole bludgers. I invite the honourable senator to draw my attention to specific instances where the unemployed have been so referred to. I would certainly deny that I have ever said that. I think it is a most unfortunate note to inject into this matter. I thoroughly reject the first point made by the honourable senator in his question .

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the rest of the question is concerned, there has always been a very strict income test for the unemployment benefit, stricter than is applied to other forms of social security payment. The reason for that, of course, is that the benefit is available for people who are subject to the work test and it has been seen as income which ought to be available only if income cannot be earned. This Government has made a number of moves to ease that income test. The most recent moves were made in the last Budget when the free limit was raised from $3 to $10 a week for young unemployed persons and, I think, from $6 to $10 a week for others, making it uniform for all unemployed. At the same time the income over which there is a partial withdrawal of benefit was also extended. The unemployed may now earn, over and above the $10 a week, $50 a week and merely lose part of the unemployment benefit. At the level of $60 a week there is a removal of $25 of the unemployment benefit. So there is that incentive for the unemployed to undertake part time work where it is available. By that means they can improve their situation.

After earning $60 a week there is a dollar for dollar withdrawal. That used to apply right from the start. Under this Government it has been liberalised up to that $60 level. I can understand why, during a period when unemployment is more serious and where the application of the work test is obviously much more difficult because there is less work available for those seeking it, the matter of further liberalisation should be raised. I can say only that that is a matter which I will certainly bear in mind and which I am sure the Government will consider when it is looking at these questions of benefits. As far as the provision for children is concerned, in the same way I would accept that that is a matter which ought to be examined from time to time to try to make sure that the provision is adequate.

The idea that the Government should apply the same income test to the unemployed as it applies to pensioners is one which I think is only superficially attractive. The difficulty with it is that if we applied that income test one would go on paying part unemployment benefit to a person in employment with an income of over $15,000 a year. As far as the pension income test is concerned, a married pensioner continues to receive a part pension up to a private income of $307 a week. There would, I think, be some concern in the community if people who were employed part time and earning anything between $12 ,000 and $15,000 a year were at the same time receiving some supplement in the way of unemployment benefit. I think different considerations apply. I do not, however, in making that point, deny that we should review that income limit from time to time. We have done that in a number of Budgets, as I say, most recently last August.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am appalled by the Minister's statement that something like the provision of $10 a week to maintain a child should be a matter which needs to be looked at from time to time to see whether it is adequate. Would he jeopardise the health of one of his own children by restricting the amount allocated to that child's upkeep to $10 a week?

—That is the sort of question which again does no credit to the questioner. It remains true in Australia in 1982 that an unemployment beneficiary with a number of children can be better off on unemployment benefit than in a lowly paid job. In other words, the allowances which are made for married unemployed are such that a man working on the minimum wage with a large family may indeed be worse off employed than if he were unemployed. The Government has addressed that problem with the proposal to introduce a family income supplement for employed families. But the manner in which the question is asked adds nothing to our understanding of the problem which is raised. As I said before, all these matters are examined on a regular basis. In the last Budget adjustments were made to the earnings provision for the unemployed, which acknowledged the difficult situation in which many unemployed people find themselves.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. One is to look at pupil-teacher ratios-class sizes-and the other is to look at the total number of dollars applied to the running of schools. ANSWER.PARA: I have two tables which set out these points. I imagine that honourable senators will not want me to go through the figures one by one. —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. —It is true that the supporting parent's benefit is not one of those social security benefits which are dependent upon a period of residency.
