SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation as covered by Senator Walsh must be related to Part IVA of the legislation which is now in existence and stops schemes of the nature outlined by him occurring. Senator Walsh, I think, is developing the argument to the effect that, if sub-clause 3 (12) reflects Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act principles, the kind of situation that it excludes from the recoupment tax would , if it occurred now, fall outside that Act. But I think that we have to look at the typical case. Where at the time of sale a company has not been assessed to tax, the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act applies if there was a reasonable expectation that tax would be payable. I must repeat that: If there was a reasonable expectation that there would be a future tax liability.

SPEECH.PARA: Entering into a tax avoidance scheme could, in theory, operate to prevent that reasonable expectation arising. As I said earlier, in shorthand, I say 'in theory' because the practical reality is that Part IVA, along with the Government's earlier anti-tax avoidance legislation, is so wide-ranging that it would be hard in the extreme to imagine that there could now be a paper scheme of avoidance which could reasonably be expected to succeed in a purpose of tax avoidance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of that, I should like the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) to confirm-given what she has said it seems that there is no alternative but to confirm it-that the statement from Mr Sainsbury, which I am about to quote, is wrong. Mr Sainsbury said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his 25 July statement made it quite clear that this legislation was meant to catch cases of the nature of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. It was well known when the first draft of the Bill came out and we examined it that there were many other cases that would be caught, cases which would extend well outside the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. That was never the intention of the Government.
Referring to sub-clause (12) of clause 3, Mr Sainsbury continued later:
This has brought the Bill into line with the original intention.

Firstly, I seek confirmation from the Minister that that statement of Mr Sainsbury is wrong. If that is forthcoming, that leaves the Government with no rationale whatsoever-at least, no publicly stated rationale-for the insertion of sub-clause (12) of clause 3. If there is such a rationale, will the Minister state it publicly now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that clause 3 (12) restores the original intention of the Government with regard to that, and as regards the fine detail of what Mr Sainsbury has said, that is not an accurate statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under clause 5, and perhaps in parts of clause 4, and certainly in clause 6 and other clauses, there are problems associated with promoters and definitions of promoters.
—The Committee is dealing with clause 5 at present.

—Yes, Mr Chairman, I am alluding to that clause. The matters to which I am speaking occur under other clauses as well. It seems to me that there are some problems about the definitions. The McCabe-Lafranchi report is still recognised as the most thorough study to date of events relating to bottom-of- the-harbour companies. That investigation took three years to complete. It involved the investigators in many hundreds of interviews with parties connected with all parts of the transactions, from vendors through to the ultimate and final purchasers. The conclusions of the report are most specific. I refer particularly to pages 12 and 13 of volume 1. Here the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no evidence the vendor directors or shareholders or agents knew:
(a) that the companies were on-sold by the dealer;
(b) that the remaining funds in the companies were removed by the dealer;
(c) that the dealer made no attempt to treat the contingent taxation liability of the companies;
(d) that the dealer did not meet prior year tax provisions in respect of which funds had been handed over by the vendor.

The legislation does not treat vendor-shareholders and agents in the same manner . Under the legislation vendor-shareholders are required to pay tax on the benefit they received-that is, tax on the net income of the company sold. Further, they are given the option of not contesting the assessment, thereby obtaining the opportunity to pay by instalments over a minimum period of 12 months, free of interest or penalty, the sum owing. Agents are not. They are treated in the same way as purchasers-strippers, by definition-contrary to the conclusions outlined in the McCabe-Lafranchi report. Agents are to share a joint and several liability requirement to return 100 per cent of all income. That is not taxation but confiscation. There is no provision in the Bill to admit to the taxation liability and the right to pay by instalments in the same manner as the vendor. As the Government will probably point out, some of these matters overlap into other clauses. I hope that the Government is taking account of the problems that there are with the existing definition of the promoters class.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to liabilities and which legislation is relevant to particular schemes, the previous answer of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) was not as specific as I would have liked. She stated that the insertion of clause 3 (12) in the second edition of the Bill had restored the Government's original intention. She said that the matters of detail to which Mr Sainsbury referred were not correct. The Minister was less specific than I would have liked. Mr Sainsbury said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . when the first draft of the Bill came out and we examined it . . . there were many other cases that would be caught, cases which would extend well outside the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act.

He went on to say that clause 3 (12) was inserted in order to prevent this legislation going outside the scope of the 1980 Act. I ask whether Mr Sainsbury' s statement is correct. Would this Bill with sub-clause (12) of clause 3 deleted from it-that is the form in which it originally appeared-have gone beyond the scope of the 1980 Act and caught schemes and people who would not have been affected by the 1980 Act had it been in existence throughout the 1970s?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I state again that the statement made by Mr Sainsbury is not accurate. Clause 3 (12) was placed in the Bill to cover the intention of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Government that it should operate in the way I outlined earlier. The company referred to had not been involved in fraud in that case and it was rendered incapable of paying its debts. As I said earlier, the situation outlined by Mr Sainsbury is not accurate. I cannot take the matter any further than that.

—I take it from what the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) has just said that the Government does not regard as fraudulent a case such as the one I now outline. An owner of a company with current year profits sells off all the physical assets of the operating company to a parallel company also owned by him. The original company then has nothing but cash and a contingent tax liability. The cash is sold for 95c in the dollar along with the contingent tax liability of 33c in the dollar. The liability to pay tax is then determined by the actions of the dealer- promoter following the purchase of the company-actions over which the original vendor-shareholder has no control and of which it is continually asserted he could have had no knowledge. Arbitrary and capricious law could scarcely go beyond that. The real point I want to make is that somebody who sets up such an artificial and blatantly contrived arrangement as to turn into cash all the assets of a company in order to sell the cash to a promoter for 95c in the dollar, along with a contingent tax liability of 33c in the dollar, is in the judgment of this Government not engaging in a fraudulent scheme. That tells us a great deal about the ethics and morals of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fraudulent action comes later in the case that has been mentioned by Senator Walsh. It does not come until the company is rendered incapable of paying its tax responsibilities.

—According to the definition given by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), the vendor- shareholders are guilty of no fraud and the arguments put up by Senator Withers come into operation-they should not be penalised. No matter where the Government turns in trying to defend this legislation after it put clause 3 (12) into it, it turns up a blind tunnel.
—That is right.

—Senator Withers is saying that that is right. Of course it is right. At least Senator Withers to this extent has been consistent in what he has said about the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill. He might have been inconsistent about a few other things in the past, but we will come to that later on. I am glad that Senator Withers agrees-I presume quite a few other Liberal senators agree-that once clause 3 (12) was inserted into the Bill the rationale for its existence evaporated. It went up in smoke. I ask one more question. Can the Minister for Finance refer me to the section in the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) of 25 July which says or even implies that it was not the Government's intention to recover contingent tax liabilities from vendor -shareholders where the dealer-promoter, at a time when the vendor-shareholder had no control of the company, attempted a tax avoidance scheme of which, so we are told, the vendor-shareholder had absolutely no knowledge? Are we falling back on this fraudulent excuse offered by the Government that the intention was only to catch those people involved in fraud even though the people who the Minister now tells us were involved in the fraud were not the vendor- shareholders at all but some other persons who were involved after the vendor- shareholders had disposed of the company? We are back in the situation where the liability to pay is determined by somebody else's fraudulent action, not by one' s own action. A few heads on the other side of the chamber are nodding. I do not know whether the Government agrees with me but a number of its senators obviously do. That is the absurd position into which the Government has now got itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I comment briefly in response to Senator Walsh's question. I do not have the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) with me, but the Treasurer made reference to the illegal evasion of tax and the fraud on the part of some people concerned. I will have the Treasurer's statement turned up and show to Senator Walsh the reference he has sought. In general terms, those were the words of the Treasurer .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I modestly seek some clarification from the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle). At the very grave risk of inflicting upon myself some diabolical disease by agreeing with Senator Walsh can I--
—At least you stand up and openly defend the crooks. This mob only defends a section of them.
—Order! The Committee is dealing with clause 5. I call Senator Crichton-Browne.

—I understand that, in a general sense, referring as Senator Walsh has to clause 3 (12), there is a distinction between those who are innocent and those who are guilty. This very much comes back to the thrust of the argument that has been put by some honourable senators on this side of the chamber. I think it is also an argument that is weighing in the hearts of honourable senators on the other side of the chamber. As I understand the situation, this sub-clause really draws a distinction between those who sold companies that were immediately stripped of their assets and dropped into the harbour-if I may use that inadequate expression-and those companies that were sold to promoters who sought, as an objective judgment, to use the words of the legislation, to offset or extinguish the profits in an avoidance scheme. If the companies were subsequently stripped and went to the bottom of the harbour, the responsibility does not rest with the innocent primary vendor-shareholders.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 6 agreed to.
Proposed new clause 6A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 31, after clause 6, insert the following clause:
'6A. (1) Where-
(a) but for this section, a vendors taxable amount would exist in relation to a person; and
(b) the person establishes that-

(i) before the sale of the shares in the company that brought into existence the vendors taxable amount, he did not know, and had no reason to suspect, that an arrangement or transaction that secured or achieved, in relation to the company, the result referred to in paragraph 5 (1) (h) or 5 (2) (h) had been entered into or was intended to be entered into;
(ii) he had no reason to believe that the amount or value paid or given in respect of the sale of the shares was excessive; and

(iii) by reason of the lack of knowledge with respect to the matters referred to in sub-paragraphs (i) and (ii), the person had so managed his assets that payment of the tax imposed on that vendors taxable amount by the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax-Vendors) Act 1982 would result in severe hardship to the person,
the vendors taxable amount shall not be taken to exist or to have existed in relation to the person.'.

This proposed new clause has been publicised as a so-called innocence clause. But it goes further than the innocence clause proposed by Liberal Party senators . I believe they will be moving for the adoption of their own innocence clause if this one is defeated and I would support that clause also. I will not make a lengthy speech about this proposed new clause because the matter has been canvassed very widely by the Press, on television and on radio. My amendment simply has two components. It deals with those people who were involved in actions which are caught by the provisions of this legislation. They committed those actions genuinely believing that they were acting within the law on advice from professional experts-accountants or lawyers-or not believing that they were undertaking any actions that might be construed as immoral or improper. Those people should be excused from the provisions of this legislation provided they can now prove that they would suffer hardship under the tax liability that can be imposed by the Taxation Commissioner under this Bill. In other words the aggrieved person has to prove two components and the onus is on him or her. Firstly, the person has to prove that he or she was innocent and, secondly, that if the provisions of this new Bill fall upon him or her hardship will be caused.

I do have sympathy, on a matter of basic principle, with those who are to be protected by the innocence clause which is to be moved by some Liberal senators. I do have sympathy with that and will support it. I do not have a great deal of heart burning for-I will not mention names-the person who acted in innocence, who is a millionaire and who made another million out of these procedures. In principle I will support that, but I have a great deal more sympathy for the person who acted in innocence, who was advised properly and who was meticulous in asking his advisers: 'Is this within the law?', and was assured at all times that it was. To permit the Commissioner of Taxation to go back five years, eight years or whatever and impose several thousand or several hundred thousand dollars back tax is unjust.

I have given examples in speeches before in this Senate. To give a very over- simplified example I refer to a man and wife who had a small business. They owned a corner store and were barely literate and barely numerative but had paid money to a good lawyer or a good accountant to advise them on tax matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no such thing.

—Senator Grimes says that there is no such thing as a good lawyer. I am beginning to think so. If the word 'good' is used in a moral sense, I am beginning to think the honourable senator might be right. According to Senator Evans, all the good ones go into parliament. The couple I referred to were advised by their lawyer or accountant to sell their business. Dozens of bits of paper were shoved under their noses which they signed, not knowing what they were. I can understand people, particularly those who are middle aged or elderly , not understanding the sorts of things that lawyers and accountants thrust under their noses. Let us say that the couple I mentioned got a relatively comfortable sum for their business, say, $100,000. Eight years ago, in 1974, they retired to Gosford or somewhere and bought a weekend shack.
—Widows and orphans. The country is full of them.

—Senator Evans does not do himself any justice when he adopts this smart-Alick sort of attitude. If he cannot understand that there could well be some-maybe not many-people who will be genuinely affected by this legislation--
—Genuinely cleaned up by not paying their tax to the extent of $46 ,000 in the example that you used.
—Order! Senator Evans, Senator Chipp has the floor.

—The trouble with Senator Evans is that he judges everybody, even me, by his own bright intellectual standards. He ought to have some humility sometimes and realise that not everybody is as smart as he is or as smart as he thinks he is. There are other people who are not quite as smart as Senator Evans . Those are the people for whom I have some sympathy.

SPEECH.PARA: To conclude, I return to the example I was giving. These people have now retired, are eight years older, are in their mid or late 60s and have received a taxation assessment of $46,000 from the Commissioner of Taxation. I believe that if a person or persons in that situation can prove innocence-the onus is on them -and can prove hardship with the imposition of this back tax at this stage, the provisions of this Bill should not apply to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment before the Committee moved by Senator Chipp seeks to relieve vendors from liability to recoupment tax if they establish a state of innocence about post-sale action that has made the company unable to pay its taxes, had no reason to believe the price of the shares was excessive and accordingly had so managed the assets that payment of recoupment tax would result in severe hardship to them. In other words there would have to be innocence, however people view that, combined with resultant severe hardship. The Government is not in a position to accept this amendment that has been moved by Senator Chipp because we do not think that innocence on the part of the vendors, however that is measured, warrants exclusion from the legislation. The legislation is here to recoup evaded company tax from those who have benefited from its non payment. That being so, their knowledge or lack of knowledge about post-sale treatment of the company is not a relevant consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendment does, I know, add another element to innocence, and that is some measurement of severe hardship. The Government does not believe that the considerations mentioned by Senator Chipp warrant adoption of the provision that has been moved by him. Insofar as the person has difficulty in meeting in a timely way the recoupment tax liability established by the legisation, the powers that the Commissioner of Taxation will have under the Bill to defer payment and even not to charge a late payment penalty, seem to the Government to be an adequate response to any difficulties that may arise. If hardship is so severe that payment would amount to a ruinous imposition the relief provisions in the income tax law and those that are to be adopted for the purposes of this Bill will allow relief from payment to be granted by the relief board. For these reasons the Government does not accept this amendment and I urge the Committee to reject it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment that has been moved by Senator Chipp. I believe it does not go as far as the foreshadowed contingent notice of motion which I and a number of my colleagues put down some time ago, because it has in it an inherent feature of hardship. Whilst I applaud and admire the integrity that Senator Chipp has shown in terms of making a value judgment about these things, I am not satisfied that hardship ought to be the only qualification for innocence. One is either innocent or not innocent. If being innocent and being wealthy is a disqualification, I find myself at some variance. If being innocent and poor is a qualification, I think that is limiting the scope too much. But I support the fundamental thrust and proposition that is put forward by Senator Chipp. He very clearly, like so many of us, identified, recognised and had communication with people in precisely the predicament mentioned.
—Ones who Senator Evans says don't exist.

—That is right. Well, he believes in Father Christmas. What essentially happened was that many people sold companies, believing they were legitimately acting within the law, after obtaining the best legal and accounting advice in the land, and having fulfilled their legal obligations felt that they had discharged their commitment under the Income Tax Assessment Act. They are now being visited by the sin of this legislation, some 10 years later. Some still do not know whether they are going to be visited by this sin, but some do. As a result of prudent common sense and reasonable and pragmatic decisions concerning their financial affairs they now find themselves in a situation of absolute hardship. I find it terribly depressing. I am not concerned about the companies but it is bad for the community for a government to seek to impinge and impose on people in this way. I support Senator Chipp's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those honourable senators who voted to leave clause 3 (12) in the Bill are obliged to support Senator Chipp's amendment because clause 3 (12) lets some rather arbitrarily selected-that is a charitable view-vendor-shareholders off the hook. This amendment seeks to let some more off the hook. The amendment Senator Crichton-Browne will move later on effectively would let them all off. For those who are interested in following a consistent line having voted to leave clause 3 (12) in, it is logically inescapable that they would vote for Senator Chipp's amendment. I might add that the Opposition, which tried to remove clause 3 (12) will, therefore, for the same reason, although from the obverse side, not be supporting Senator Chipp's amendment. The people who are in an utterly indefensible position are those-the majority of Government senators-who voted to insert clause 3 (12) and who will now vote against this amendment. Their position, I repeat, is logically indefensible.
—I am terrified to agree with you.

—The honourable senator is consistent, too. He wants to let them all off and we will be voting against that proposal as well, of course. But the reasons why we will not support Senator Chipp's amendment, why we will not support Senator Crichton-Browne's amendment and why we tried to exclude the ' partial innocence' clause, clause 3 (12), from the Bill which the Government presented are basically the same.

SPEECH.PARA: How innocent were these people? I will say again what most of them did. They had an operating company-say it was a factory-and they sold off the premises; they sold the land; they sold all the equipment: They sold it as a going concern to a company which they also owned. So, the target company which was to be sold had nothing but cash and they sold the cash for 95c in the dollar. We are asked to believe that these people did not realise they were getting involved in something shonky. Now, really, who sells money for 95c in the dollar unless they believe there is something shonky about it?

TALK.START.PARA: —Money changers do it all the time.

—Not for as big a margin as that. They also sold with it, of course, a contingent tax liability of anything up to 46c in the dollar. That is how innocent these people were. They set up another company for no reason other than to purchase all the assets of the company that they originally owned and they then sold the money for 95c in the dollar along with a contingent tax liability of anything up to 46c in the dollar. And we are asked to believe that these people are innocent.
—No, that is not the only possible scenario.

—It is the scenario that covers the overwhelming majority of them. And in all cases they sold companies with contingent tax liabilities at prices which rendered the purchaser unable to pay that liability without losing money on the deal. They were not that stupid that they did not realise there was some shonky business involved in it somewhere, whether they knew the precise details of it or not.
—I agree with what you are saying. But, if they cannot prove their innocence they will not come within the provisions of the clause.

—I am coming to that in a minute, Senator Chipp. Senator Chipp has added to that the 'hardship' clause. He apparently has sympathy for people who, as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said, ran off with stolen money many years ago and now have to pay it back and might have difficulty in doing so. I suggest that Senator Chipp should save his sympathy for the people who conducted honest businesses or attempted to conduct honest businesses all the way along, who paid the tax which they should have paid and went bankrupt because they could not compete with people who were not paying tax. That is where the sympathy should be directed-to those people who conducted honest businesses and paid the tax that they should have paid and who could not compete with sleazy operators who used people such as Brian Maher to get them out of their tax liabilities. The sympathy should go to people who went broke because they could not compete with crooks.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point is that Senator Chipp's clause would I think guarantee that, if not all, certainly very nearly all of the individual cases went to court as the vendor-shareholders attempted to establish both their so-called innocence and their hardship.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing wrong with that, is there?

—I have acknowledged that Senator Chipp's position on this, whether or not one agrees with it, is logically consistent. The rationale for this Bill, however, is that only people who broke laws which already existed will be caught. The Bill is only introduced, so the Government says, in order to avoid virtually every case being contested in court and to avoid the delays in collecting the money that that entails. So the honourable senator is consistent. But that is not his rationale; it is the Government's rationale, having accepted , of course, that it destroyed its own rationale when it wrote sub-clause (12) of clause 3 into the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said at the end of my speech in the second reading debate, the Australian Labor Party still supports the legislation because it is better than nothing, but only just better than nothing. It was weak legislation in the beginning and it has been substantially watered down by the Government since it was first introduced. But we will not support this innocence clause because the people concerned were not innocent. They knew that they were getting a financial benefit somehow or other because tax would not be paid. The sympathy should be reserved for the people who are in competition with the tax dodgers and the tax cheats, and who went broke because they paid their tax and they could not compete with those who did not.

Finally, this clause, of course, would ensure that almost all cases, if not every case, finish up in court and no money at all would be recovered for probably a number of years. Our criticism of this legislation in its original form was that it did not go far enough. It was weak, limp legislation, as Senator Button said, and this is another attempt to water it down further. Therefore, we will not support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question posed is: How innocent were these people? I put to honourable senators that that is not for us to judge . Since the days of the Magna Carta, at least I would have thought that question should have been decided by people holding judicial office and that one should never legislate to find a class guilty. That is the sort of thing which Hitler did. He said: 'All Jews are guilty of being Jews, so we will shove them all into the gas ovens'. That sort of class legislation is wrong.
—Oh, cut it out! All they are doing is making them pay back the money that they got away with.

—That is what Senator Walsh is saying. He is saying that all vendor-shareholders are crooks, therefore they shall pay. I think it was Senator Chipp who said that these people believed they were acting within the law. They not only believed that they were acting within the law, they were in fact acting within the law, otherwise this legislation would not be necessary. This is the dilemma which the Government has been in from day one. If we do something which is philosophically wrong, we get into a legislative mess and a bigger administrative mess. Because the Government started in a way which was philosophically wrong, we are now in our present mess.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been said that there is no such thing as innocent people. Some 10,000 tax assessments will be issued. Even if only one out of 10,000 assessments is wrong, that one person ought to have some recourse. Are we just going to convict a whole class of people, irrespective of what the individual cases may be? If there are no innocent people, the Government has no worries about this clause because nobody will prove it and the Government will collect all of the money. Senator Walsh said that the Government may have to wait years for its money. I thought that under either the current or the proposed provisions, leaving aside some of the oddities contained in the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982, under a normal assessment a person would pay 100 per cent now, and then quarrel about it. If the person does not pay the full amount, an interest rate of 20 per cent must be paid. So why will there be a delay in collecting the revenue? As I understand it, once the assessment is issued to the vendor- shareholders, unless they come under the 12 months clause, the amount is payable forthwith, even if they appeal to a board of review or to a court. That could still apply to the innocence clause, so the Government will still collect its money. The Government has no answer to the question: If there are no innocents, what is wrong with an innocence clause? Why is the Government worried about having such a clause put in? Is it because it is afraid that too many people will be able to show that they are innocent?

We are told that there are people who never knew. What about the ultimate vendor-shareholder in the public company where the public company owned subsidiaries that were sold off and bottomed? Did the 10,000 shareholders in that public company know what their directors were doing? I admit they may have got a benefit; they most likely did get an indirect benefit. However, there were shareholders in large public companies who would not have known that this was happening. I know of individual cases--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Treamog? They didn't get any money either.

—The honourable senator is worried about Treamog Ltd. What about all the shareholders in Metro Industries Pty Ltd? Does the honourable senator think that every individual shareholder in Metro Industries knew what was happening? Does he think that the 30,000 shareholders in TVW Enterprises knew about the five companies? In fact, the board of directors did not know until the whole thing blew up because the companies had been disposed of by their accountants and lawyers. Neither Senator Walsh nor the Government is prepared to admit to what happens as part of practical commercial life. I would like Senator Walsh to tell me about those individual shareholders in Metro Industries, assuming that the directors did what they have been alleged to have done. Those individual shareholders did not have a clue what was happening. There was no way they could discover what was happening.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, the Government, admittedly for administrative reasons, has said that where the tax liability is less than $100 an assessment will not issue. But that is not being done as a matter of generosity, decency, morality or any of the other sorts of things. It is being done just because it is cheaper not to issue assessments, and for no other reason. So we have the ridiculous situation where I pay nothing if I have a liability of $99 but if I have a liability of $101 I pay $101. Where is the fairness between two taxpayers in that system?

TALK.START.PARA: —There isn't. Your innocence or guilt depends on a dollar either way.

—Innocence or guilt depends on $2 either way. It is a remarkable situation that on the one hand we have a piece of legislation which has been trumpeted as being moral, fair and decent, to catch people worse than 1,000 Norm Gallaghers, to recoup stolen money and all the rest of the political hyperbole and rhetoric that has gone on, and on the other hand we have all the injustices at the margin. Unfortunately the Bill will pass unamended, but not without some struggle. However, I predict that all the hard cases will keep coming in. Remember Mrs Moo who was recently such an embarrassment to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Australian Taxation Office? A Mrs Moo is eventually going to turn up in this case. Everybody is going to say: 'But it was not my fault because I didn't know the gun was loaded'. That is going to be the excuse. I can see, eventually, some one-eyed, one-armed, one-legged World War digger, dying of terminal cancer in a wheel-chair, being evicted because he cannot pay $101 tax. This is sure to happen out of 10,000 assessments. I can see it sticking out a mile. The Treasurer will rush off to give him an apology and his $101 back.

SPEECH.PARA: All we are saying is that occasionally we should just give the average taxpayer a go. The onus of proof is on the taxpayer. That proof is not easy to establish; it is very difficult to establish. He should get off. I would suggest that most of these cases will not get cluttered up in the courts. Some people will try lodging an objection. When that fails they will pay up if they have the money. If not, they will go before a taxation board of review. In any event, I do not see that the Government is going to wait for its money.

But irrespective of that, I come back to what I was talking about in my speech during the second reading debate. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly following one or two remarks made by Senator Walsh about the philosophy of this matter. SPEECH.PARA: I also want to remark on the chilling honesty of his speeches and those made on behalf of the Australian Labor Party. I think it is time to say to all of those Liberal and National Party senators who are not in the chamber that they should listen to the chilling honesty of the speeches in this debate of Labor senators. They are 100 per cent honest in their belief about retrospectivity. There is a chilling frankness, a cold-blooded frankness, in what Senator Walsh is saying about this legislation. He has said, I think, that the legislation is weak, limp -wristed. No doubt Senator Walsh will become Minister for Finance or will occupy another senior position when a Labor government gets into office, which may be very soon. What Senator Walsh has been saying in all honesty is: 'Wait until we get into power in one year's time or five years' time. We will make this retrospective legislation look like a Sunday school picnic'. I hope Senator Martyr will forgive the allusion to a strange rite in the Protestant church.

The Labor Party's policy has been laid out. The Labor Party was honest in the last election campaign when it said very frankly that it would introduce retrospective legislation to deal with tax cheats and tax dodgers. That comment was rebutted by the Liberal Party three or four days before the last election. I have newspaper cuttings in front of me which illustrate that. In a last minute plea, I ask Liberal senators to wake up to themselves. They should know what this legislation is doing. It is making illegal something which was legal when a person did it. It is being made illegal because it was immoral or because the intention was to avoid or minimise tax.

Let us assume that Senator Walsh is Minister for Finance or the Treasurer. Let us take the case of a person who is running a small business which is making a reasonable profit, which is expanding and doing very well. Let us assume that this businessman is a reputable person who has a reputable accountant who goes to him and says: 'You are now doing so well, I advise you to transfer your proprietorship business into a private company because in that way, by using the law as it exists, you will be able to minimise your tax or save tax.'. This man may then say to his accountant: 'I do not want to do anything illegal'. The accountant could say: 'This is the section of the Act; it is perfectly legal'. The businessman may repeat: 'I do not want to do anything improper'. The accountant may reply: 'There is nothing improper about it'. The businessman may then say: 'I do not want to do anything immoral'. The accountant could say: ' There it is in black and white. You are perfectly at liberty to form your single trader business into a company or a partnership if you like'. Let us say that he did it last year.

Next year Senator Walsh could be Treasurer and he might say: 'This was a transaction, an act, entered into for the main purpose of saving or minimising tax. Therefore, I will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to date back X number of years and catch the person who performed that act'. That sort of action is possible. What Senators Walsh and Evans are saying to the Liberal Party in crystal clear terms is that that is what the Labor Party will do because people are doing this for the purpose of minimising tax. The warning is there. If the Liberal Party sets the example by passing this kind of legislation, it will have opened a Pandora's box which it will never be able to close. Will people who 10 years ago took out insurance policies that they could not afford because the insurance salesman said that the Commissioner of Taxation would pay half be caught? Are we going to backdate legislation to catch them? I am not suggesting that the Labor Party has that intention. What has been done in terms of the principle in this legislation gives the Labor Party the green light so to do. I am very sorry that the only people now in this chamber on the Government side are those who, as I understand it, are committed to the civil liberties view which I am putting, a view which is in this place. I am disappointed that others who I know care about the protection of civil liberties as opposed to the extravagances of politicians and who are supporting this legislation are not in the chamber to participate in what has so far been a first class debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should name them.

—No, I am not going to name them. That is the honourable senator's prerogative. I raise that element of danger, commend the Labor Party for its honesty and express grave doubts about the wisdom of those Liberals who have taken this course of utter pragmatic, materialistic expediency.

the nature and level of penalties proposed being, I understand, a source of difficulty for some of your colleagues . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I thought Senator Withers hit a new height of hyperbole and rhetoric by using the terms he used. He said that what we are proposing to do is similar to what Hitler did. Hitler said that the Jews as a class were guilty; so he shoved them all into Auschwitz and elsewhere.

—He was advised by your mate in the Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth, Mr O'Sullivan, that, among other things, a prosecution would not succeed- no, I am sorry; I do not think that Mr O'Sullivan gave that advice. As the McCabe-Lafranchi report said, they got nothing for their investment but scrip in a worthless company devoid of assets and with sham directors. That matter leads me to the point raised by Senator Withers that the courts ought to decide innocence or otherwise. I agree. A criminal offence or perhaps something short of a criminal offence ought to be decided by the courts and not by the Parliament. I might add that 27 years ago two people were sent to gaol by this Parliament. I do not think that is anything of which the Parliament should be proud. In this case criminal sanctions are not being imposed. The most that anyone has to do is pay back the money that he should not have had in the first place. With respect to Mr Horgan, I note that the Government apparently does not share Senator Withers's view as to whether the courts should decide guilt or innocence. The Government has asked Mr von Doussa to determine whether the transactions organised by Horgan were illegal or dishonest. Mr von Doussa is being asked to determine that and not the courts. Because of the litigation that will certainly be greatly expanded if an amendment such as this is carried and because the most that anyone will have to do is pay back the money which he should not have had in the first place, we will not support this amendment or any related amendment. TALK.START.PARA: —I have some concern about clause 7 which refers to promoters. I expressed concern to the Government about the collection of the outstanding revenue that the Government alleges is due from promoters. I must say that I speak in the way of amelioration rather than on the matter of principle. I have said during the second reading debate and during argument beforehand that I believed all of these people are innocent. That being so, I adduced an argument about the necessity of the Government's legislation. So I believe that my remarks provide amelioration to which I hope the Government will listen.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, the Australian Taxation Office and, indeed, some agents falling within the category of promoters, want to see outstanding revenue paid and collected expeditiously with the least amount of difficulty. The effect of the promoters' clause of the legislation does not achieve this aim. It gives no incentive whatsoever to those members of the eligible promoters' class who were not strippers to admit to any assessment or to make any payment without a fight. In fact, the opposite effect is achieved. Each person is jointly and severally liable for the gross fees in relation to each company purchased. This will be far greater than the actual fee that the agency received. The aim of the Bill is to recoup 100 per cent of such fees received. In order to join others who benefited-those who shared fully or in part in the fee split-only two options are permitted. The first is to pay a proportion of the amount assessed and then commence court proceedings enjoining others, or, secondly, to pay no amount and wait for the Commissioner to commence recovery proceedings and then join others in that action. In both cases the party concerned is still responsible for the whole of the amount claimed, including interest and penalties.

Furthermore, the legislation is drafted is such a way that there is no certainty that the court will exercise its discretion to allow the joining of other parties. The court is asked to consider both the benefits received and the nature and extent of participation in the arrangements without defining what the latter clause means. I think examples can be produced. I will not bore the Senate with the details of a case I have which shows clearly just the sort of thing that can happen. I am submitting that the agent has no alternative but to attempt to enjoin all of the other parties in his actions. They genuinely obtained a benefit from the money the agent received and paid tax on it.

It seems to me that as the law presently stands there is no choice for an agent or anyone else in the promoters' class to do anything other than fight the Commissioner to the limit of their financial resources. Conceivably it might take several years for the courts to decide a minimum of, say, 500 cases. The Taxation Office itself refers to something like 4,600 cases. Those affected may as well enjoy while they can their assets on a diminishing basis relative to legal fees. Ultimately, whatever has been accumulated over a lifetime's work will be lost in legal fees and those defined as promoters will be bankrupted.

The Taxation Office will not receive any revenue and will waste many man-hours in contesting all of these cases. An additional side effect, of course, is that the whole process will result in the clogging up for years to come of an already overworked court system. There are many solutions to this problem. I simply have had the problem pointed out to me. I leave it in the hands of the Government and presumably the Taxation Office to come up with some solution. It may even be that a restructuring will achieve the Government's aim of fairness.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 40, after clause 8, insert the following new clause:

'8A. A primary taxable amount shall not be taken to exist in relation to a person in relation to the sale of shares or of an interest in shares in relation to an amount of ordinary company tax or undistributed profits tax payable by a company in relation to a year of income unless, immediately before the time of sale of the shares or interest in shares, the person knew or believed, or could reasonably be expected to have known or believed, that-
(1) ordinary company tax or undistributed profits tax, as the case may be, was payable, or would become payable, by the company in relation to the year of income; and

(b) an arrangement or transaction had been or would be entered into or carried out for the purpose of securing or achieving the result that the company would not be able to pay to the Commissioner all of the ordinary company tax or undistributed profits tax, as the case may be, that was, or would become, payable by the company in relation to the year of income.'.

It has been put on more than one occasion, and presumably will be put again, that this legislation is not about innocence and guilt. Frankly, I find that argument at complete variance with the object and purpose of this legislation. The legislation does in fact cast a penalty which is to be imposed on vendor- shareholders retrospectively creating an artificial tax year-a new tax year-and transferring the tax liability of one person on to another. The real intent of the legislation frankly is to make one taxpayer liable for another taxpayer's debt. If honourable senators disagree with that proposition I suggest that they would have to disagree with the proposition that we have double taxation on company profits. There is a clear distinction between the tax entity of the corporation and the tax entity of the individual shareholder.

This legislation, of course, has resulted directly from the fraudulent activity of certain members of the community. I believe it is absolutely bizarre to suggest that this new heavy retrospective taxation now being levelled on certain vendor-shareholders does not in fact impose a new liability. Of course, the facts of the matter are that this legislation is intended to strike not only at the innocent vendor-shareholders but also at the guilty-the fraudulent promoters , fraudulent directors and fraudulent shareholders. The point is that the legislation does not seek to draw a distinction between innocent and guilty persons. They are all subject to the same penalty. People who acted quite properly within the law, people who obtained the best legal advice and accounting advice-in many cases they had their transactions sanctioned by the High Court of Australia or the Supreme Court of South Australia-are now having cast upon them a new taxation liability, a new burden. Lumped together in this legislation are the honest and the dishonest, the avoiders and the evaders and the guilty and the innocent. They are all subject to this legislation. This legislation does not draw distinction between innocence and guilt.

I am glad that certain members of the Opposition concede that innocent people are involved. In fact, Mr Willis, in a debate in the House of Representatives when a similar amendment to this was proposed, said that the Australian Labor Party rejected the amendment because there were not very many innocent vendor- shareholders. I disagree with his judgment as to the number involved. That, of course, is properly a matter for the courts to determine. We do share one common view-that is, that innocent people are trapped by this legislation. Not to accept that innocent people are involved frankly is not to understand this legislation. Whatever one's view, I would have thought that amongst reasonable men it is universally accepted that the courts of our land are the proper places to determine whether people are innocent or guilty. The laws of the land are meant not only to prosecute the guilty but also to protect the innocent, to provide clarity and certainty. The purpose of this amendment is simply to reinforce that principle. In fact, the wording of the clause is such that the burden of the onus of proof will be transferred to the taxpayer and he will be encumbered with the full responsibility of proving that he did not know or believe, or could not reasonably be expected to have known or believed, certain things. That burden of proof is considerably heavier than that which is normally imposed on a taxpayer.

The argument has been put in some quarters that all vendor-shareholders are guilty. The argument has been put that if they received consideration for their shares in excess of the current year's profits less the contingent tax liability for that year they must have known that something wrong, something improper, was likely to happen to their company. I remind the Committee in the short time I have available that at that time there were a number of arrangements, a number of schemes, a number of transactions, which could quite properly and quite legally be entered into which, as I said earlier, extinguished, diminished or mitigated the tax liability. There was no suggestion at that time of any illegality or any impropriety in the way those companies were being treated. It ought to be remembered that we are not talking about 1981 or 1982; we are going back ten years. We are going back to 1972 or 1973, to a time when there was no suggestion that people were doing the sorts of things that have been demonstrated in the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union.

Many taxation lawyers and accountants of international and national standing recommended such schemes on the basis of the legitimacy of the financial transactions of vendor-shareholders It seems to me to be expecting a lot to presume that an unknowing vendor-shareholder would ask his lawyer about legal ramifications if subsequently criminals are appointed as new directors steal the money and throw the files in the bottom of the harbour. I must say that it is hardly the obvious question that a businessman would ask his legal advisers. To suggest that all the innocent vendor-shareholders who sold their companies should have known that the companies were going to end up in the hands of crooks , thieves, prostitutes, the underworld, the painters and dockers--

TALK.START.PARA: —They knew they were getting too much.

—No, they did not know they were getting too much. The honourable senator does not understand company law. I regret that because, if he did, he could make a valuable contribution to this debate. All the subsequent activities of people who finally ended up with the companies were blatantly illegal and subject to very serious penalties. I suspect that the average person would not believe that people would take their companies and conduct themselves in the way they have. I will remind honourable senators of what the McCabe- Lafranchi report had to say about the role of vendor-shareholders. The report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no evidence the vendor directors or shareholders or agents know:
(A) That the companies were sold by the dealer,
(B) That the remaining funds in the companies were removed by the dealer,
(C) That the dealer made no attempt to treat the contingent taxation liability of the companies,
(D) That the dealer did not meet prior year tax provisions in respect of which funds had been handed over by the vendor.
In fact Messrs McCabe and Lafranchi stated:

No doubt from the point of view of the vendor it must have been almost unbelievable that the contingent tax liability of a company could be avoided in the manner provided by dealers such as Brian J. Maher and Co. and Commercial Securities Limited.

There has been much debate about and emphasis on the role of private companies. I wish to touch for a moment on the role of public companies, as has been done already this afternoon. I think that about 63 public companies have been identified and listed so far as falling within the framework of this legislation , with probably in excess of 10,000 shareholders. I put to honourable senators: Is there a real argument, a persuasive argument, that those shareholders had knowledge that companies were being sold by their corporations, would find their way, by whatever route, to the bottom-of-the-harbour, and would be stripped and treated in the way they were? Of course they did not know that, but that does not relieve them of any tax liability or of the responsibilities now cast upon them, subject, of course, as we know, to certain discretionary provisions. The facts are that these people are as innocent as those involved in private companies. Yet they now find themselves subject to a very heavy taxation liability for assets they may well have sold at a loss some years ago. Clearly, the innocent and the guilty are thrown into the same situation.

I wish to refer to a matter that Senator Walsh raised this afternoon. I am always terrified that I must be wrong when I agree with him. Clause 3 sub-clause (12) of the legislation tacitly demonstrates belief in the innocence of certain groups of vendor-shareholders. The explanatory memorandum states:

The sub-clause applies where, after a target company was sold to the promoter, it entered into a scheme which is ultimately found to be unsuccessful of its purpose to reduce or eliminate the company's liabilities for the income year during which the sale occurred, and that could reasonably have been expected to eliminate or reduce the company tax payable for that year.

In that case, provided the scheme was not part of, or connected with, the arrangement which rendered the company unable to pay its company tax liabilities , and the arrangement which had that effect had not been entered into for that purpose, the amount of company tax payable will, for the purpose of ascertaining the liability of former owners and promoters to pay recoupment tax, be taken to be the amount of the company tax that would have been payable if the scheme had turned out to be successful.

That simply means that, in the event that the company was sold off to somebody who sought to offset the profit for that year in a legal tax avoidance manner but failed and it subsequently went to the bottom-of-the-harbour, no liability will be inflicted upon the vendor-shareholders.
I further repeat the words of the explanatory memorandum which states:

It is designed to ensure that the legislation will not operate to recoup unpaid company tax where the funds of a target company were removed-rendering it unable to pay tax-on the basis of an objective view as to the efficacy of a post sale tax scheme designed to reduce or eliminate tax liability.

That clause amounts simply to Russian roulette. If one was lucky or fortunate enough to sell to a promoter whose first object was not to strip the company and send it to the bottom-of-the-harbour but to seek to offset the profits in a legitimate or legal way and then it was stripped, one is safe. But if one was unlucky enough to draw the short straw and end up with a promoter who in fact immediately stripped the company and sent it to the bottom of the harbour then one suffers the sins of that person and gets caught by the provisions of the legislation. I hope the fact that that provision has been inserted by the Government demonstrates the bona fides of people who had sold their companies for a value which exceeded their value less their tax liability. I am sorry that Senator Missen has left the chamber after making an unintelligent observation.

The Government concedes that there are perfectly legitimate and perfectly legal schemes under which companies were sold for a value in excess of their profits less their contingent tax liability. As I say, it is a regrettable element of the clause that it is qualified to the extent that it is a question of whether one is lucky or unlucky as to whether one is visited by the recoupment tax legislation. It is not a question of good management, of prudence, of integrity or of innocence; it is simply a question of good luck. The fate of the shareholders rests exclusively with the integrity of the promoter.
I will conclude with an observation which was made by G. Nash, Dean and Professor of Law at Monash University, who said:
History warns us to beware of those who would do something in the name of morality or truth, for the man who knows he is right can be absolutely merciless in implementing the right.
We do not have to go back to the Spanish Inquisition or to Cromwell's Major- Generals to recognize the dangers of men who know they are right.
If retrospective legislation is to be justified on the basis that it implements the moral sense of the legislator then gone are our liberties and gone is the rule of law.

The only reason that I did not do so was that I had to return to Western Australia for a family funeral. I asked Senator Crichton-Browne to put it down for me. It was not put down by Senator Crichton-Browne as a result of pressure from any honourable senator but as a result of a request by me.

SPEECH.PARA: I say also to Senator Walsh that if he thinks my present stance is as a result of pressure from some person or persons unknown, I have news for him. I think I have been a senator for long enough and I am well known widely as enough of a rogue elephant for people to know that nobody tells me what to do or say, be he within the Liberal Party or outside the Liberal Party. I will make known my views in this Parliament irrespective of what prime ministers, parliamentary leaders, State party organisations or anybody else like to think. I have been in this place off and on for nearly 17 years. Nobody yet has told me what to say or how to think. I will thank Senator Walsh in the future not to cast imputations on what motivates me.

TALK.START.PARA: —He lives in a different world.

—I grant the honourable senator that. That is one of the reasons I could never follow the party of my father which had certain views on individual liberties for members of parliament which I could not tolerate, but I will leave that aside. I will not speak any further to the proposed new clause. I made known my views when Senator Chipp's amendment was moved. I will be voting for the amendment as moved by my colleague, Senator Crichton-Browne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not able to accept an innocence clause of the kind that has been expressed in the proposed amendment. As has been said by other honourable senators, the debate on this matter really took place during the debate on the previous innocence clause moved by Senator Chipp. I certainly recognise the motives that have influenced those honourable senators who have moved the proposed amendment and who supported the previous amendment. I understand that a number of honourable senators would support such an amendment but it is not a view which the Government holds. Perhaps we differ mainly because of the appropriateness of the amendment. It seems to the Government that the case for an innocence clause proceeds from something of a misconception of what this Bill seeks to do and the way in which it expresses its objectives. This Bill does not brand the people to whom it applies as criminals or delinquents. When its technical complexities are put to one side, the Bill says quite simply that there are those groups that benefited from the evasion of company tax which are now required to pay that unpaid company tax. Questions of guilt or innocence of a person from whom recoupment is sought have nothing to do with it. We are dealing with a situation where, by fraud on the part of some of the people concerned, company tax has been evaded. The amount of the evasion having been determined and the groups that gained from it having been fixed, the Bill simply calls for them to pay back the benefit that they ought not to have enjoyed.

SPEECH.PARA: There is, I suggest, no proper place in those conditions for former owners who would otherwise be liable to recoupment to be let off because of their innoncence and the unsavoury things that happened after the shares in the companies were sold to the promoters of these schemes. To put it bluntly, they should, innocent or not, be called on to pay to the revenue the benefit that they enjoyed because the Commonwealth revenue was deprived of the company tax concerned. If that general argument is not accepted there are some significant practical considerations also leading to the conclusion that an innocence clause should not be included in this Bill. One could take all sorts of instances but in the typical family company where perhaps only one or two of a larger number of proprietors make the effective business and investment decisions of the company and the family, an innocence clause of the kind now before us might operate to free from liability some, but not others, of the members of the family. More significantly, an innoncence clause would be most likely to cause the administration of the recoupment tax to grind to a halt. I think that has been said in other ways today. Instead of the work of recouping the unpaid tax being as relatively straightforward as the Bill would have it, it would be necessary, at assessment and review stages, to make inquiries into the presence or absence of the relative purposes or benefits on the part of the persons sought to be made liable. That is not the intent of this Bill when it is seeking to recoup tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be quite impossible.

— Administratively I would think it would be very difficult. We have said before, and I have said it today, that questions of guilt or innocence are really beside the point of whether former owners of stripped companies should be liable to pay the recoupment tax. The real point is that they have received a benefit from the evasion of the company tax and hence should simply be asked to recoup that unpaid tax. Guilt or innocence-we have been talking about it in a number of ways today-is irrelevant to this legislation. I want to repeat that. Company tax has been evaded and those, particularly the vendors who benefited by the non-payment of the company tax, are simply being asked to pay. There are those who argue that if there were an innocence clause the late payment penalty of 20 per cent will accrue and will lead to payment.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to point out that the nature of an innocence clause is such that there would be litigation about innocence. The tendency would be for each case to become a matter for litigation. I think it was also admitted during the debate on the earlier amendment that vendors did get a benefit; even shareholders in public companies gained a benefit. What the Government is saying in the whole of the philosophy behind this legislation is that those who did get a benefit by the evasion of company tax should simply return that part of the benefit which represents tax due to the revenue under the provisions of this Bill. For those reasons the Government rejects the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has set out a good answer to those people who are supporting the amendment. The essential thing is that nobody is going to have to pay back money in excess of the money which they ought to have paid in tax anything up to 10 years ago. We support the Government entirely in seeking to achieve that end. What the honourable senator has not explained is why the Government is allowing certain classes of vendor-shareholders who happen to be lucky enough or cunning enough to sell to a promoter after the vendor-shareholders have been party to setting up a highly contrived scheme which turned everything into money and then sold the money-and the promoter subsequently put the company into some failed tax avoidance scheme-not to have to repay the money that they ought to have paid in tax anything up to 10 years ago. No matter which way the Government turns, since the insertion of clause 3 (12) every escape route is a blind tunnel. I believe it is absolutely outrageous that that clause was put into the legislation belatedly, after it had first been introduced. Clause 3 (12) is arbitrary and capricious law at its worst. It is utterly disgraceful that some vendor- shareholders should pay while others get off just because they were lucky or cunning enough to sell to promoters who used tax avoidance schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: I submit there are two possible reasons why clause 3 (12) was inserted. The first is that the Government is feeble minded and cannot follow the logic of the argument, and the second is that it was written in to get particular people off the hook. One who demonstrably it does get off the hook is Denis Horgan. I might add for Senator Withers's benefit, if he is interested, that I put out 12 Press statements on this subject between the first week in June and the end of July.

TALK.START.PARA: —You called him a crook, did you?

—The honourable senator can read them if he likes. Truth is not necessarily a defence in defamation action, as the honourable senator well knows . Senator Martyr complained about another piece of retrospective legislation today, and I am grateful to him for that. I am not familiar with the details but I note in passing that he was personally involved in it and he complained about it. He has not claimed to have complained about any of the other 21 pieces of retrospective legislation passed by the Liberal Government of Charles Court in Western Australia which I have already had incorporated-
—How punitive were they?

—They were pretty punitive if one was a shareholder of Afro-West Mining and Exploration Pty Ltd, a company which had a case before the courts contesting the legality of the Ashton Joint Venture diamond claim. An amendment was pushed through the State Parliament which awarded it to the Ashton syndicate , principally to CRA Ltd, thereby nullifying legislation which had been in existence since 1906. Senator Martyr might have thought it was punitive. I believe-although I do not have the details-that a number of the other pieces of legislation from the Western Australian Government on the list which I have had incorporated were also punitive, particularly those which concern the Metropolitan Water Supply Sewerage and Drainage Board. The essential point on this so-called innocence clause is that nobody is going to have to do more than repay the money that he ought to have paid in tax many years ago. Therefore there is no justification for an innocence clause other than the fact that rather a lot more people who have evaded and avoided tax will not have to pay it back because of the limp legislation which the Government introduced and subsequently watered down; most notably sub-section (12) of clause 3.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are going to throw any sympathy around I suggest again that it ought to be saved first for those who were conducting businesses honestly and paying the tax which was due on their profits but who were forced into bankruptcy because they could not compete with other companies which were not paying tax they should have been paying. Sympathy should not go to those who very belatedly are to pay tax in inflated dollars which ought to have been paid years ago. The second group of people for whom we should reserve our sympathy, who are much more numerous, are the millions of ordinary families who, according to estimates by authorities of the eminence of Mr Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers' Association and Professor Mathews, have been paying $30 a week more tax than they ought to have paid because a minority have paid little or none. A minority of that minority will now have to pay some because of this legislation. That minority ought to be very much larger, but the legislation as it stands is better than nothing. If this so-called innocence clause were included I suggest it would be completely useless. Therefore, the Opposition will not be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter the debate very briefly. I am not one who spoke on the previous amendment moved by Senator Chipp, but when I spoke in the second reading debate I indicated that I would support the innocence amendment. I was not going to enter the debate. It is dangerous, I suppose, to be goaded into it. But I have just become too tired, sitting here, of listening to statements by Senator Walsh such as 'it is a case of people simply paying back what they owe'. It is not so simple. People ought to be reminded of what some of the implications of this legislation are. I have to admit that the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) also said that it is just a matter of people paying back a benefit they ought not to have enjoyed. One gets the impression that people who have enjoyed this benefit did nothing but put the money in the bank and sit and wait for the Government to do something about it.
—They made profits out of it.

—Senator Missen, you are tedious. Take your turn. It is not enough just to say that the people who have benefited are not criminals or delinquents. The fact is that they are people who entered into business arrangements. They made what they thought was a quite legitimate profit. They took advice; they acted in good faith. In some cases it is possible that they could have believed that the company they were selling was to be put to a very specific purpose which carried a particular tax benefit and to them the transaction might well have looked to have been a piece of sound business on the part of both the vendor and the purchaser. Were the vendors then obliged to ensure that what happened to that company was what they had been led to believe would happen to the company? There are circumstances under which people could have acted in good faith.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also the fact that simply getting this money that should have been paid, this benefit that should not have been enjoyed, could lead to some very complex results. I will not take up a great deal of time of the Senate outlining what they are. I think everybody here knows. But I just do not think it should be allowed to pass as being such a simple matter to extract this money that Senator Walsh says these people should pay. They should pay back what they owe, he said, as though somebody gave them something and now they have to pay that debt. It was not a debt at the time when they got the money. It is far more likely that the money has been invested in various ways, perhaps in further business ventures, perhaps in property, perhaps in homes. Who knows? There are indications already in some areas of the country where some of that money may have gone by what has happened to the property market. I do not pass any comment on the morality of that because I do not know the individuals involved and nobody here does.

The simple fact is that this legislation will cause hardship and it will cause hardship to people who acted in good faith and who are innocent in the terms of this innocence clause that we talk about and, indeed, to the heirs of some of the people who acted in this way. Undoubtedly a number of these people have died -that would be in accord with the law of averages-and their widows or their children will have received that benefit that, in the words of the Minister, they should not have enjoyed. That is entirely possible. They are in those terms having a benefit that they should not be enjoying. But they were not the parties to the arrangement. As I understand the legislation, they will now have to find the money to pay this tax, regardless of what were the motives of those who entered into the arrangement. The simple situation is that the Bill in total is objectionable but this clause would at least recognise the position of those people who acted in good faith, those people who believed they were not doing anything wrong but were acting strictly within the letter of the law as it then applied, as advised to them by their lawyers and their accountants, the people whose services they were hiring to give them good business and financial advice. They may have been led to believe that the arrangements that were to be entered into by the purchaser were such as would be quite persuasive. Some people suggest that everybody must have known that something was wrong. Senator Crichton-Browne in his speech gave us a couple of examples of arrangements that people might have believed were possible. The simple fact is that, as long as we give major taxation incentives to people in certain industries, the argument gets weaker. If we give a 100 per cent tax benefit, as we do in the case of certain areas of activities, and it was believed that the person purchasing the company was involved in that area of activity, it would be entirely persuasive and plausible to have sold one's business venture under these circumstances.

I believe that it is not enough to reject the notion of innocence. I believe that there was some innocence. Some people perhaps might have suspected sharp practices and not asked their accountants and lawyers the right questions. Some people, I am sure, suspected sharp practices, asked their accountants and lawyers the right questions, were not satisfied with their answers and so did not proceed. A whole range of activities was possible. It was not an intention to defraud. It was not a negligence of inquiry on behalf of the people whom we are talking about. There was genuine innocence and they should not be hounded, be open to hounding or, indeed, now suffer a financial disadvantage which may have an effect far past taking back the benefits that they have enjoyed but which, because of circumstances-of timing or whatever-may mean that the price that they pay is far heavier than if they had paid their tax. Some people might say: 'Well, serve them right'.

TALK.START.PARA: —They ought to have paid their taxes and not swindled.
—If Senator Mulvihill can say that, I do not think he has listened to a word that has been said in this debate.
—You are trying to defend all the tax evaders. It is your Government and your people who are disloyal to John Howard. You cannot defend them.

—I will be finished in eight minutes. Why does not Senator Mulvihill then make a speech? I am not attempting to defend all the tax evaders, nor have those who have been supporting this amendment. That has been clear throughout the debate. That is why I asked where Senator Mulvihill has been during this debate. His ears are closed. That is the propaganda with which he has persuaded himself to support this wretched legislation. Mr Temporary Chairman, I have forgotten where I was, but I might remember in a few minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that Senator Martin finds interjections disagreeing with her tedious. I am afraid that she has now provoked me into saying a few words on this matter, not having spoken on any of the innocence clauses. It seems to me that a sidetrack is going on with regard to this debate. It is quite right, as Senator Martin said, that some people will suffer hardship. But on the other hand many people who got more than they should have from these companies and the sale of these companies have had the money for years and have invested it. She said that people seem to think that they put it all in the bank. I do not think that they all put it in the bank. I think they turned it over and made profits. They are not being taxed for those profits. They have had the money for some years. An amount of $580m has been calculated as being not paid by the frauds and disgraceful behaviour of people. The people who are now being brought to book in this are not necessarily people who were involved in that fraud. They may be, in a sense, 'innocent'. They may not have known where the money was coming from and why they were doing so well. But somebody must suffer. Is it to be the ordinary pay-as-you-earn taxpayer of this community who has suffered in the past because of these defalcations; or is the money to be collected or not?

SPEECH.PARA: The merging into a question of innocence is, in my view, very serious. It is one thing to be opposed entirely to this legislation. I understand the sincerity of a number of honourable senators on this side who think that. But to then promote an innocence clause is, to my mind, a much more serious thing. It is to degut, to take away everything from the Bill. It is to ensure that because things are in the minds of people, governments are expected to prove what was in the minds of people 10 years ago. Of course, we know that the collections will not be made. We know that the success of an innocence clause inserted into this Bill would make the Bill a sham and the Government, of course, would thereby--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why? Because they are innocent?

—No, not because they are innocent, but because we cannot prove the things that are in people's minds. But innocence is not the question. It is a question of collection of tax moneys. Those people who have inherited these moneys by reason of the frauds of others and who are now called upon to recoup that money are the people who should pay and not the really innocent taxpayers of this community who pay more tax and who do not get tax reductions because of the clever frauds that have been made in the past. That is the simple proposition; all the nonsense about innocence and so forth in this matter today has nothing to do with it. It is a matter of who in fairness is going to repay this money.
