The Government is right to resist to the hilt any idea of an innocence clause because that actually would wreck this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without wishing to belabour the debate too much, and for those--
—But you are.
—In that case I will speak for considerably longer. However, for those people who are suffering from the debate I might tell them that the cricket score is seven for 220.
—Order! I suggest that the honourable senator direct his remarks to the clause.

—It is interesting to observe that one hears that there is no such thing as innocence, that everybody is guilty and that the money that has been improperly kept by certain people ought to be repaid. It is very interesting to observe how consciences sway from one side of morality to the other. We hear people talk about the poor old pay-as-you-earn taxpayers. I do not hear rage, indignation or criticism of the PAYE people-so far untouched because it is politically wise not to do so-who think it is very appropriate to accept a significant discount if they are building, a pergola, a barbecue or an extension to their home. Such behaviour is socially acceptable. We have not yet arrived at the level of morality where such behaviour is retrospectively outlawed and subject to outrage.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to touch on two matters raised by Senator Walsh. As usual, Senator Walsh never spoils a good story with the truth. He made some claims about members of the finance committee of the Liberal Party of Western Australia being tax evaders. I put it to him, as I have put before, that if he knows that to be the case I think he quite properly ought to notify the Commissioner of Taxation. He ought to declare who these people are. They will be subject to section 86E, or whatever the appropriate provision is, of the Income Tax Assessment Act. It already provides for such action. I find remarkable any suggestion that people in the Liberal Party have provided funds in any unnatural way; given the events of the Iraqi funny money scheme that the Australian Labor Party tried to launch itself into.

This legislation really comes down to a question of innocence. If people entered into schemes and arrangements that have subsequently been found to be illegal, given the heavy onus of the burden of proof that has been cast upon them, and it has been demonstrated that they did nothing wrong or had no reason to believe anything was improper in their transactions, I do not believe they should be visited by legislation which is retrospective to 1972.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder what sort of Australian parliament I am serving in when I hear a Minister ridiculing the idea that there are innocent people and admitting that they will be caught by this legislation but showing no recognition of the suffering that is going to fall upon them. I am also concerned when people who could be best described as professional bleeding hearts in this place and who are always complaining about infractions of human rights get up and also lump everyone, innocent and guilty, into one Bill and the penalties that come from it. Let us stop all the sophistry about this legislation being a recoupment measure. The legislation seeks to impose extra taxation on people who in some cases complied with the law as it stood at the time. It is true that, to use Senator Walsh's words, there were crooks. Let us get them under the legislation that exists now and which has existed previously. We have no need for a Bill of the sort we are considering. However, there are innocent people and I for one will stand up for their right to be protected under the legislation of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to reply just briefly to the extraordinary comments which Senator Crichton-Browne made. He said that he knows that the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer is evading tax wholesale because everybody who has a barbecue built or an addition to a house built pays in cash and gets a discount. If he knows of such cases it is his duty to tell the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation about them, and I hope he will. He then said that I mentioned that at least five-we have found five; there could well be more- members of the Liberal Party's finance committee in Western Australia sold companies to Brian Maher when he was President of the Western Australian Liberal Party. He said that if I know about this I ought to tell the Commissioner. Unfortunately, all that I know is that they sold companies to the Maher organisation. I do not know the financial details because there has been no investigation in the Corporate Affairs Office in Western Australia as there has been in Melbourne and Sydney, although the results of those investigations have not yet been announced. As a former President of the Western Australian Liberal Party and still, I understand, an infuential member of the Western Australian Liberal Party-
—And a very good one.
—I think it was Bill Wreford who said that you were the best stacker of branches that party has ever had and he was a member of the State Council of the Liberal Party.
—Order! I ask Senator Walsh to address the Chair and confine his remarks to proposed new clause 8A.

—I am sorry, Mr Chairman. I should not respond to interjections. Senator Crichton-Browne ought to be pressing the Liberal Government of Western Australia, which has been in office for nearly nine years, to conduct such an investigation. I note he has not done so. It seems to me that there could be very good reasons of self interest why he has not done such a thing.

—I raise a point of order. Senator Walsh is implying that there is a good reason why I have not pressed a State matter. Implicit in that is that there is some impropriety. This is the third time during this debate that he has climbed back into the gutter. I ask that you rule that he withdraw the remark, Mr Chairman.
—I think there was imputation of an improper motive in the statement of Senator Walsh. I ask him to withdraw it.
—If such hypersensitivity is around here that he could have read that into my comment, I will withdraw.
—I ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw. We will have a proper investigation by the Corporate Affairs Office in Western Australia and then we will catch you.
—Order! Senator Walsh, I think that there was again an infringement of Standing Order 418. I ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw.
—I suggest that you stick to proposed new clause 8A.

—I was just about to round off my comments. I must make a couple of comments about what Senator Martin said. She was very concerned about the heirs of people who many years ago did not pay tax that ought to have been paid. Frankly, I am much more concerned about the heirs of the people who did pay the tax that they ought to have paid many years ago than the heirs of the people who did not. I am even more concerned about the millions of ordinary families who have been ripped off for years by people who were not paying the tax that they ought to have been paying. Nobody is going to be responsible to pay more tax than ought to have been paid years ago. They have had the use of the money for anything up to 10 years free of interest and they will pay it off in inflated dollars. I think they have been treated very lightly by this legislation. Regrettably, of course, a lot of those who are equally guilty will not be affected by the legislation at all and they ought to be. Of course, what this amendment seeks to do is not to redress the anomalies, the inequalities and the inequities. What it seeks to do is to add to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That proposed new clause 8A (Senator Crichton-Browne's amendment) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Martyr

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to record the fact that again no pairs were granted. As Senator Thomas signed this contingent notice of motion, I am quite sure he would have voted for it if he had been here.

INTERJECT.PARA: Clauses 9 to 17-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 57, clause 18, after sub-clause (8), insert the following new sub- clause:

'(8A) Sub-section (8) applies whether or not an objection against the assessment was made by the company and, where an objection was made by the company against the assessment, that sub-section applies notwithstanding that the objection by the company has been finalised or is to be taken to have been finalised for the purposes of paragraphs 5 (1) (f) and 5 (2) (f).'

The Treasurer (Mr Howard) in this second reading speech, when introducing the revised legislation on 21 October, indicated that the Government had concluded that all former shareholders should be served with a company assessment notice, 'the only qualification being that the person's whereabouts is known or, in the case of a company, it is not dormant'. In fact, the legislation does nothing of the kind. The legislation retains the exclusion included in the initial legislation; that is, the service on the shareholder is not necessary if the Commissioner has reason to believe that prior service on the company brought the contents of the assessment to the shareholder's notice. If the vendor had been aware of the assessment after the sale, as has been said already many times in this debate, there was no basis on which he or she could have objected because that vendor then did not hold any office in the company nor had any rights in that company. Consequently, under the law, although they may have been aware of the notice, they were deprived of any legal remedy to undertake action. The effect of clause 18 of the legislation is one of Russian roulette in that those who by chance happened to have received a company notice of assessment before this legislation brought about the assessment which they could do nothing about, will now be denied the right to object against the liabilities of the company. I believe this ought to be rectified. The amendment that I have moved aims to give to each person liable to pay the tax that the Senate has voted that they should now pay the same rights that the company had whether or not that company had lodged an objection. In some cases appeals might have been abandoned by the buyer of the company whereas, if the vendor had retained that company, the appeal may have been pursued. Each person who is potentially liable for the recoupment tax that the Senate has now decided upon I believe must be given the opportunity to pursue any objection which the company may have pursued in relation to any company tax outstanding or claimed to be outstanding. I believe that it is only in that way that the justice and fairness about which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and others have spoken will be able to be pursued in a legal way. Each person ought to be able now to make that objection which could have been made by the company, notwithstanding the other clauses upon which we have already voted. If this clause were added, it would enable that to occur. The Senate ought to allow this amendment so that at least one area of possible anomalies can be removed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendment. The terms of the amendment are based on the faulty premise that in a case where a company has already exercised rights of objection and appeal against an assessment there are no further rights of objection and appeal against the copy of the assessment served on vendor- shareholders. The Government's advice is that an earlier or concurrent exercise of rights of objection or appeal by the company would not exclude a vendor- shareholder nominated by a majority of those in the representative class from also exercising the rights of objection and appeal given by sub-clause 18 (8). Therefore the amendment is unnecessary and the Government rejects it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no reason to doubt that the assessment of the facts given by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) is correct. For those reasons, the Opposition will not be supporting the amendment either.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause 18 agreed to.
Clauses 19 to 22-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask about the objections that are able to be lodged and whether my understanding of this matter is correct. As I read clauses 20 and 21 it seems to me that this piece of revised legislation allows those who do not object against the company tax time to pay but those who do object are denied time to pay. Is that reading correct? If it is correct, it seems to me to be absolute terror tactics. I am asking for clarification of clauses 20 and 21, because that is the way that I read them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under clause 21 time to pay without penalty is given. That is a condition of the arrangement.
—May I ask the question again? Is it the context that those who do not object get time to pay, but that those who object do not get any time to pay? Is that correct?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those who do not object get time to pay, without interest. That is one of the conditions that are drawn. Where they object there is not time to pay without interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to record my objection to that. As Senator Macklin says, this is a terror tactic. One goes along with what the Government bullies one into doing. If a person thinks he has a case to challenge the Government's ruling he is at a distinct financial disadvantage. That is not the sort of justice that I am prepared to support.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 23 (Evidence).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 63, clause 23, sub-clause (1), line 33, leave out ''conclusive evidence'', insert ''prima facie evidence''.

Clause 23 refers to a certificate signed by the Commissioner of Taxation and states that an amount of company tax specified in a certificate is due and payable by a company and that on a date specified in the certificate that company tax remained unpaid. This document is to be taken as conclusive evidence . My amendment to clause 23 would change the wording to refer to prima facie evidence that this was the case. It is a minor amendment but it would mean that a person could at least contend that a tax is due and payable or that the tax is unpaid. I can understand one of the reasons the Government may wish to have what is an unusual clause in there. Similar clauses are normally handled on the basis of prima facie evidence rather than conclusive evidence being available. I understand that one of the reasons might be that the Government has aimed at overcoming the problem of a lack of company records. I think that the price of the provision surely is the denial of a fair defence in relation to at least two items by vendor-shareholders, who themselves are also at a severe disadvantage because they do not have records either. Let us not forget that what was actually done to the companies about which we are talking was not done by the vendors but by somebody else. When the vendors seek to pursue their objection they are at as much disadvantage as the Government is in relation to this matter . It seems to me to be at least fair and equitable that we should not put this additional impost on them regarding the notion of having conclusive evidence, which seems to me to be a very odd type of proposition anyway. Senator Missen has drawn this to our attention concerning another Bill in which such a provision was attempted. It was changed from conclusive evidence to prima facie evidence. I believe in this situation that would be sufficient to carry the Government's will in relation to this clause. Surely it would be cleaner all round to have that normal provision included.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects this amendment to clause 23 that has been moved by Senator Macklin. The purpose of this clause is to ensure that in proceedings in relation to recoupment tax the amount of company tax and the fact that it has not been paid are not matters which can be raised as a defence. That is entirely appropriate in circumstances where the company tax assessment is capable of being made subject to objection and appeal processes and where a recoupment tax assessment can be disputed by a similar process. Clause 23 has been varied from the form it took in the original Bill introduced in the House of Representatives and not proceeded with in that it has now been made clear that a certificate is not conclusive evidence in cases where the company assessment itself is subject to appeal proceedings. Clause 23 is modelled on and complements section 177 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 which is incorporated into this Bill by clause 4 (1). In combination that clause and section ensure, in accordance with the long accepted practice, that assessments to tax are capable of challenge only through the established appeal mechanisms and not as a defence to an action for recovery of the tax.

—Do I understand from that that we are to have no bureaucratic errors? For example, are we to make absolutely sure that company tax, for instance, has remained unpaid? Is the assumption that a person cannot dispute a decision as to whether company tax has been paid?
—Mr Chairman, surely that question warrants an answer.
—I thought so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Macklin always wants the instant response to something that he raises, even though in this case it is a misunderstanding of the Bill itself.
—A response in the Committee stage, Senator, that is all.

— That is right, even though there is a misunderstanding about what I said in regard to the appeal provisions and the objection that can be raised. I said that the company tax assessment itself is capable of being made subject to an objection and appeal process and a recoupment tax assessment can be disputed by a similar process. It is modelled on section 177 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Because of the appeal mechanisms which allow any objections to be raised, the amendment cannot be supported by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been said to me-it is a proposition with which I agree-that, if one is as totally opposed as I am to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill, one should oppose it even at the third reading stage.
—Custer's last stand.

—My friend refers to Custer's last stand. It reminds me of a reply Senator Withers gave the other day. I do not know that it is entirely in conformity with the Standing Orders, but I draw to Senator Missen's attention that Custer's last stand was at a place called Little Big Horn. I say no more than that because I would not want to outrage the Standing Orders or the sensibilities of anybody concerned. It seems to me that, as I am in total opposition to this Bill, I have to keep trying in the hope that maybe the final words will have some effect on the silent civil libertarians on my side of the chamber of whom I have not seen very much during this debate. I am wondering whether latterly in listening to the debate, some of them have come to the conclusion that this is essentially bad legislation because of its retrospective element and because a new tax has to be established. It was with some shock that I actually heard speakers on both sides of this chamber asserting quite definitely and quite strongly that there was no element at all of retrospectivity in this legislation. I do not know how they could possibly come to that conclusion when two lots of explanatory memoranda are available, one put out by the Treasurer, Mr John Howard, and the other by the Minister representing the Treasurer in this place, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. Both of them adverted in their explanatory memoranda to the retrospective element in this legislation. I do not know how anybody could possibly assert that there is no element of retrospectivity. But people have done so.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Missen is muttering again. It seems to me that he has spent most of his time during this debate muttering about how disloyal people are to the Government and how they cannot see that all these people are guilty, that they are all crooks and have all evaded tax and all have to pay. I simply say to all those people who keep telling me that there is no element of retrospectivity in this legislation and that the money was always owed: Why is it necessary for the Government to make fresh legislation to create a new tax and to apply it retrospectively? There is only one reason for that, and that reason is that what these people did-I am not talking about the morality of it-was perfectly legal at the time. The whole proof is to be found in the collective Bills and in the explanatory memoranda. It is all there for anyone with basic common sense to see . The essential point about this legislation is that it is retrospective and a new tax has had to be created in order to get what the Government says is owed to it. There is not any doubt at all that it is a new tax and that it is retrospective. That is the only point I am trying to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whom are you arguing against?

—People on our side of the chamber. I have seen one after the other stand up and I have heard them say that this really is not retrospective legislation. I have also heard people on the other side of the chamber say that. Senator Walsh has been saying it during almost all of the Committee stage. He has been saying that this money was always owed. He said that the people who evaded tax are all crooks. He is making all these judgments. He is making judgments about people when he says that they evaded tax. We all know that evasion of tax is illegal; that is stated on all the taxation forms. Senator Walsh cannot say without any qualification at all that people evaded tax. The fact is that he just does not know; he is just guessing. With a fertile mind for making slander in this coward's castle Senator Walsh has been very successful in naming people so that their reputations are just simply ruined forever. They have had no trial at all except the one given them by Senator Walsh. No charges have been laid, except in this place under parliamentary privilege. Senator Walsh has been challenged time and time again to take his charges into the street, into the public forum, and just see how long he would last in law. It is all very well for him to use this coward's castle. It is all very well to use the privilege of this Parliament to defame people, to make charges against them, to accuse them of being tax evaders and crooks and to keep naming them week after week. But Sentor Walsh has not done this out in the open forum. He would get a writ at law if he did. He knows that so he keeps using this coward's castle. This has been the standard of this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose that I at least can be grateful that I am a poor man, financially anyway, and probably always will be. But the charges have been made by Senator Walsh and others that people in the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party and in the State Council have taken money from all sorts of places in order to fight the retrospectivity that is embodied in this legislation. I would have to say that I have received no money. I have seen no one passing out this money. Indeed, if Senator Walsh and people on the other side want to blame certain people in Western Australia for opposing the retrospective legislation they had better start blaming me because I have had quite a deal to do with the framing of a strong opinion in Western Australia against this dreadful legislation. I tell the Senate and anyone else who is interested that I have not received a penny for that except my parliamentary salary. I think that salary was well earned. This is what I am here for-to protect the people of this country against legislation which is as bad as this.

I reject utterly the charges of Senator Walsh and anybody else in this place who suggests that the Western Australian Council of the Liberal Party of Australia has been bought by people who are against retrospectivity. Those charges are utterly unsuitable. My standing here and saying what I am saying is the rejection of charges by Opposition members. They are not worth a snap of the fingers. It is easy to come in here and point the finger and make charges. That is the whole burden of the Opposition's case. It is a shameful thing that our Government should be dragooned, pushed and pulled into such legislation as this in order to catch up on people who are presumed to be guilty when everyone in this place knows that under the ordinary rules of evidence they are totally innocent. No charges have been presented by anybody. I have always said that if these people are as bad and as dangerous as the Government and others have said they are, let them be prosecuted according to the law as it is now. What is the answer I get from my learned colleagues here?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is just a filibuster until 6.30 p.m.

—The answer I get is that it is just evasion, that they are all crooks. Honourable senators opposite know as well as I do that there is no charge being made. Not one single charge has been made against anybody but they have been judged guilty. This is the fundamental fault in the Opposition's case and in the Government's case. Indeed, Senator Withers spoke in his speech the other evening about what the called the gamekeepers theory. I call it the creation of a scapegoat. Scapegoats have been created in order to draw attention away from things that perhaps ought to have been done, and done sooner. I say no more about that but scapegoats are being created in this community. As I said before, charges have been made in this coward's castle under privilege but not one single thing is said outside. Not one single attempt is made by people on the other side to charge these people under the law, to inform on them, to take the case outside under law.

SPEECH.PARA: I have made it abundantly plain that my argument is an argument for the principle of certainty. I believe that that principle has been abolutely outraged by this legislation. I have heard people say during this debate that the principle of certainty is a lot of nonsense. Indeed, the same sort of people have said that certainty cannot apply in this case; that these people cannot be protected by the principle of certainty because they are all rogues. What is the principle of certainty about? The principle of certainty is about protecting everybody so that they have a certainty before the law about their course of action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Legal nonsense.

—My learned friend said: 'Legal nonsense.' He did not contribute much to this debate except a lot of muttering. He is the one who stands up and claims to respect civil liberties and civil libertarians in this chamber. His failure on this occasion has been absolutely deplorable. He has joined in with the accusers on the other side who, without proof, have condemned people to a shameful financial death. That is what they have done. There are people who are now worried about their futures and who are worried because people who they once knew as their friends financially and otherwise will not even address them and will walk past them in the street. That is the sort of thing they do. It is the sort of thing I cannot understand. There are one or two civil libertarians on the Opposition side too. What about the great defender of civil liberties, Senator Evans? What has he done in this particular case?
—Where were you when kids were being sent to Vietnam? You were secretary of the Democratic Labor Party then.

—Senator Evans has joined with Labor senators in traducing people . That is absolutely disgraceful. That is what Senator Walsh is doing now. He is condemning me retrospectively for what I did rightly then. That is quite in keeping with the sorts of accusations he has made for the full time of this debate. It is absolutely shameful. I will, in time to come, say something about other disgraceful confiscations I have seen in Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I would not want the Senate to assume that all that Senator Walsh has said about punitive retrospectivity by the Western Australian Government is true. The worst punitive confiscation ever undertaken in the history of this nation was against two men in Western Australia by a government of their calibre. It stole the mining leases from Hancock and Wright. That is something the Opposition ought to be absolutely ashamed of.

TALK.START.PARA: —Charlie Court did that.

—No, it was done in the time of the Tonkin Labor Government. Don May was the Minister for Mines. I am still totally and completely opposed to every aspect of this Bill. The most shameful thing about it is the creation of scapegoats. The Opposition will do anything to put the collective guilt of the community on to a few people.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd: Aboriginal Development Commission

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd: Aboriginal Development Commission

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Thursday night last during the adjournment debate Senator Haines read into Hansard a telegram from the Chairman of the Point McLeay Community Council. In my brief remarks in response to that I said that I would like to know who solicited the telegram. I had certain information given to me over the weekend. No doubt Senator Haines will be able to verify whether it is correct. I understand that a message was received from either Senator Haines or her office seeking certain information and wanting to know in what way I had upset the people of Point McLeay. As I said the other night, I have not upset the people of Point McLeay in any way. They have approached me over many years to get some assistance for them. As members of this Senate who have been here for nearly as long as I have would know, I have consistently brought forward here matters on behalf of the people of Point McLeay. I have never done it on my own accord.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am concerned about-I did say this the other night-is that Senator Haines , in reading the telegram, referred to a document which allegedly was a report of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. That document, which is so often quoted in many cases, is a 29-page document which is entitled 'History of the Ralkon Company operation and dispute-Events leading up to complaint to Commonwealth Ombudsman'. Of course, there is a whole series of details in that document. But in no way, shape or form is it a report from the Commonwealth Ombudsman. Senator Peter Baume knows that because he has received letters on the subject. I will have to delay the Senate for some time to read into the record a letter from the Ombudsman so that people who are being misled and used by others can see for themselves what the position is. I am prepared to make a lot of documentation available to these people, as I made it available to Senator Peter Baume when he was Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare many years ago. I have to say that, much to my concern, my files have increased tenfold since then. However, I did acquaint the people of Point McLeay-the directors of the Ralkon Agricultural Co. and, particularly, the Chairman-with the text of that telegram and the text of Senator Haines's remarks. Over the weekend they delivered a letter to me by hand and asked that I read it into Hansard. I will do so at the request of Mr Spencer Rigney, who is the Chairman. It is written on Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd letterhead and dated 27 November. It states:
Senator Geoff McLaren,
The Senate,
Parliament House,
Canberra.
Dear Senator McLaren,
We have read the telegram sent to Senator Haines on 25.11.82 and signed by Henry. It makes sorry reading and only shows that a proper inquiry into this is long overdue.

Why Henry put his name to it we would not know. It is not the first time he has signed something that he knew was not true. The last time it concerned ourselves and he told us that he signed because he was afraid of losing his job. We can only assume something of the same this time. The people of Pt McLeay knew nothing of it and it does not reflect their feelings. The people of Pt McLeay are by now heartily sick of the whole filthy business.
Henry may have signed this telegram. He certainly did not write it. Whoever did write it is obviously afraid of a proper inquiry and is trying to use Senator Haines for their own ends.
This Company represents the whole community of Pt McLeay. It is their company. On behalf of the people we ask you to continue to seek for the inquiry and we thank you for your persistence.
We would hope that Senator Haines will now join with you in seeking justice.
Yours sincerely, SPENCER RIGNEY Chairman

I say here and now that I have a notice of motion on the Notice Paper-it has been there since about May last year-seeking to set up a Senate select committee to inquire into all of the problems. I think the proposed terms of reference cover just about every aspect that could be covered, going back a very long time . In view of the concern that Senator Haines expressed in the Senate the other night in making accusations against me-unsubstantiated, I might say, by anybody from the Point McLeay community-I expect that the Australian Democrats will at least support me if that notice of motion comes on for debate. I expect also the support of Senator Teague, who has had some interest in this matter. I have documentation of his visits to the area. By way of his interjections last Thursday night he accused me of setting black against black. I never use the word 'black'. I talk about these people as Aborigines, as they should be talked about. Senator Teague said:
Black against black as well.

That was in response to the use by Senator Haines of the expression 'black against white'. I have never endeavoured to divide the people of the area. At all times I have endeavoured to bring about a peaceful solution to the problems that have existed at Point McLeay for a very long time.

It is not the first time that telegrams such as this have originated from the Point McLeay Community Council. On 13 March last year I received a telegram at my office, then at 6 Third Street, Murray Bridge. I have never been one to hide anything that comes to my notice to try to solve this problem. The telegram reads:

This Aboriginal council protests vigorously against the remarks made by yourself under parliamentary privilege in the Senate, March 3rd, 1981. You have obviously been misled in fact to the detriment of this council's community affairs and well being. We hold you to your statement 'if I have been wrong in what I have been saying on behalf of these people I will be quite prepared to apologise to the Senate for what I have said over the years'.
That telegram is signed by Councillor Ronald Wilson, Chairman, Point McLeay Community Council. That is the telegram that I received. On the same date I sent a telegram to Mr Ronald Wilson. It reads:

Wish to acknowledge receipt your telegram on behalf of your council. Please advise me immediately of the full text of the resolution passed by your council and the date on which council meeting was held.

That telegram has my signature attached to it. On the same day I checked with Telecom Australia as to the origin of the telegram I received. I was advised that it was phoned from an office. My staff did some further checking and I found that that telegram originated from the office of Deloitte, Haskins and Sells in Murray Bridge, a firm of accountants just around the corner from my office. The people who sent the telegram journeyed to Murray Bridge, which is a long way, and instead of talking to me they went to their accountants and lodged a telegram by phone to be sent around the corner to my office. I received a reply telegram by telephone on Saturday, 14 March 1981 at 8.30 a.m. It was lodged at Narrung on Friday, 13 March 1981 at 6.20 p.m. The text of that telegram reads:

Acknowledge your telegram of 13th. Relevant minutes will be posted as requested . Suggest meeting between ourselves to discuss this resolution and all other problems affecting the Aboriginal community at Point McLeay.

That telegram was signed by Ronald Wilson. To this day I have not received a copy of the minutes of that meeting. I am led to believe, but I cannot substantiate it, that no such meeting was ever held. There may have been a meeting of one or two people. One of those people is still there. I refer to the administrator at Point McLeay, Mr Probyn. To this day I have not received a copy of the minutes and the people at Point McLeay are not aware whether any official meeting was held. On 16 March an unsolicited petition-I did not ask for it-was delivered to my office. It was signed by 42 residents of Point McLeay. I also received a copy of the local council roll-that is, the people entitled to vote at the Point McLeay Community Council elections. That petition, dated 16 March 1981, states:

We, the undersigned People of Point McLeay want to have free and open Council Elections on 28th March as we have always done. We do not agree with certain members of the Council who are going behind our backs on important issues. We wish to thank Senator McLaren for standing up for us in Parliament, especially for what he said on 3rd March 1981.

My speech in the adjournment debate of that date is documented in Hansard. I have a copy here. I advise any people who are now starting to show an interest in the problems of Point McLeay to read it. They should go back through the Hansard indexes for many years and look at the problems which I have brought before the Senate. When I looked at the names of the people who signed this petition, I noticed that one was an H. J. Rankine, J.P. So 18 months ago Henry Rankine who signed this petition was saying that he agreed with what I was trying to do for the people. It should be borne in mind, as I said on Thursday, that Henry Rankine was among the first group of people who visited me and asked me to do something to assist them.

I have said in the Parliament before that they wanted me to contact the reporters of the This Day Tonight program and ask them to go to Point McLeay to do a program on it. I talked them out of this. I explained to them and convinced them that an exercise like that would only be a 24-hour wonder and then people would forget about it. I said that I would raise it in Parliament which I did, firstly during the Estimates committee hearings. That is all documented. People who read the answers will see that the Aboriginal enterprise grants which had been stopped would be paid if the Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd would sack the white manager. I note in the message that has come from Senator Haines that I am sticking up for one white person at Point McLeay. That has never been my desire at all. I have asked the Aboriginal people while Mr Hillock was not present whether they were satisfied with the work he was doing and whether they wanted him removed. They have always said they are satisfied with him. It is the decision of the directors and shareholders of the company that he should continue to be the manager of that company. I can do no more than accept the word of those people for whom I have great respect.

The petition that was sent to me was signed by 42 people out of 61 people entitled to vote at the Council. I think that that is conclusive proof that the majority of people at Point McLeay are not concerned, as Senator Haines said when she read out the telegram, that I am causing trouble at Point McLeay. I would say that over 90 per cent of the residents of Point McLeay are shareholders by law of this registered company. They have won court cases on this subject. It takes a very small number of those shareholders to call for a special extraordinary meeting to discuss the problems. That has never happened.

Mr Bob Randall, who was a Liberal Party member of the State Government until the last State election, and I visited Point McLeay during the year before last by invitation of the Ralkon Agricultural Co. to attend its annual general meeting. That meeting was advertised, as it should be by law. When we got there we found that the administrator, Mr Probyn, had locked the community hall and put some people in a bus and taken them to Adelaide. If it had not been for the good offices of the principal of the school who unlocked the school so that the meeting could be held there, that meeting would have had to be held under a tree . Many things need to be answered at Point McLeay.

I have documentation of resolutions passed by the Council that the administrator, by an instruction or a motion passed by the Council, should be a resident of the settlement. I ask the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) who represents the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs whether he will check to see whether Mr Probyn is a resident of the settlement or whether he travels a great number of miles each day to attend to his duties and whether he gets paid a travelling allowance which involves a certain amount of money. It is a large amount of money. I ask Senator Baume to check that out. I also ask him whether a white person is employed as a bookkeeper who again travels each day from Murray Bridge to the settlement. Further, I ask him whether the money-as I have said before, this is the reason I asked a lot of these questions during the Aboriginal Development Commission estimates-which is appropriated by this Parliament to both the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the ADC is being wisely spent. I think it is my duty as a member of parliament to pose those questions. We come now to 18 August 1981. I refer to a telegram I received from Mr Spencer Rigney, who is Chairman of the Ralkon Agricultural Co. The telegram states:

ADC interference has established procedures causing unnecessary dissension within this community. Urgent that select committee of inquiry requested by you earlier be got under way as a matter of urgency for the good of this community.

The telegram is signed by Spencer Rigney. I did not solicit that telegram. Senator Haines has read into Hansard a telegram from the present Chairman of the Council, Mr Henry Rankine, claiming that I am causing problems. Mr Spencer Rigney, who has been a resident of Point McLeay all his life, was not, by some manipulation of the electoral roll at the last election in March, allowed to stand as a candidate for the Council. This is something that the State Government has to look at to see that there are no further malpractices at election time. Every March when the annual election is due to be held there are problems. I have oodles of correspondence about that. There is also a documentary film in the Parliamentary Library which contains certain accusations which were made by the returning officer's wife as to some pressure that was brought to bear on the returning officer. I will not go into all that. All of that will come out if the Government will agree to hold a public inquiry.

It may well be, as I have said, that people who are members of the company will finish up with egg on their face; I might finish up with egg on my face. But I am so convinced of the problem that exists there and I am so determined that justice be done that I think an inquiry should be held. I take offence at the remarks made by Senator Haines that I am trying to gain some cheap political kudos. They are not her exact words but that is what she really meant about my raising the matter of Ralkon. Senator Baume would know, as would the present Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Wilson), that no political advantage is to be gained by any politician who stands up in public and fights the cause of Aborigines because eventually one will find that one's head will be on the block .

I have been pursuing this matter for many years. People have said to me that I am a fool to keep it going. I came into this Parliament with the desire to represent the underdog. I have tried to do that on all occasions. If I am wrong, as I have said-this also relates to the telegram which I have read into the Hansard-I will apologise to the Senate and anybody else whom I might have offended. But, of course, we will not know whether I have accused anybody falsely until a public inquiry is held. It is not beyond the capabilities of the Government to have an inquiry. It could be that we may not need a Senate select committee, as I have suggested, to look into this matter. Another form of inquiry could be held. The committee of which Senator Baume was chairman felt that this matter was out of its jurisdiction and it therefore gave it to the Ombudsman.

However, I think what the Ombudsman said also has to be read into the record. I refer to a letter from Professor Richardson to me dated 2 March 1981. I hope again that this will lay to rest these false accusations which have been made. A document is continually surfacing which, it is said, is the final report of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. Anybody who reads the Commonwealth Ombudsman Act would know that there is no way that the Ombudsman can bring down a final report unless the people of Ralkon change their mind. Due to the lapse of time the people of Ralkon asked him to discontinue his inquiry. The Ombudsman wrote to me on 2 March in the following terms:
Dear Senator McLaren,
On 19 January 1981 I wrote to the Chairman of the Ralkon Agricultural Company Pty Ltd following conversations between you and this office and Mr Bob Randall and myself.
I mentioned a while ago that Bob Randall is an ex-member of a Liberal government in South Australia. The letter continued:
My letter to Ralkon contained the following:
I sought from the Secretary comments on the apparently unauthorised circulation of Mr Crotty's letter of October 1978 addressed to Mr Koolmatrie.

The Secretary's response, not unexpectedly, is to the effect that he is unable to ascertain whether the copying and circulation of the letter took place within his Department. He has provided details of the enquiries he made which show that the relevant files are recorded as having been in storage for many months previous to our enquiry, and there is no further information which would enable him to speculate fruitfully on how the document came to be circulated.

I can understand your company's concern at the circulation so long after the event of a letter which contained only the preliminary views of this office in relation to your complaint, but I have to say that if, as seems possible, people with interests opposed to the company are responsible, the likelihood of action by this office being successful in preventing the activity is small. I should, therefore, be interested to have your reaction to another possible course, which while it will not guarantee that the document ceases to be circulated, may go some way towards nullifying its effect. Should you wish it, I would be prepared to furnish you with a statement to the effect that the letter in question, dated 25 October 1978, represented preliminary conclusions only by this office, and that those conclusions and the evidence upon which they were based were contested by your company. It would be open to you to use such a statement to counter the effects of the circulation of the document. Beyond that, however, I find it difficult to perceive any other solution which could be of much assistance to you.
I have not heard further from the Company but if I do, of course, I will, if requested, provide the statement.
Yours sincerely, J. E. RICHARDSON Commonwealth Ombudsman

Again I have read into the Hansard record this letter from Professor Richardson which shows that there is no such thing as a completed Ombudsman's report. Yet people repeatedly say that there is such a report. I do not know why they are doing it. I think Professor Richardson hit the nail on the head when he said in part of his letter that they have a grouch, or words to that effect, against the company. I have another letter which I think should be read into the Hansard record. It is signed by Mr Spencer Rigney, Chairman of the Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd. It was written to the Adelaide Advertiser in response to a letter to the editor by Mr Charles Perkins. Unfortunately, Mr Rigney's letter was never published. I will publish it now. It states:
Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd. Loveday Bay Road Narrung, S.A. 5259 29 September 1981
The Editor
Advertiser Newspapers Ltd
King William St.,
Adelaide, S.A. 5000
Dear Sir,
I wish to set on record certain facts relating to matters raised in the letter from Mr Charles Perkins (the Advertiser 28/9/81).

Ralkon was established in 1975 at the instigation of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs following our representation to conduct farming operations on behalf of the aboriginal people of Point McLeay. The Department advised those residents that after the formation of the company they would each receive shares in the company. Following the formation the Department advised that the shares should be held by the Point McLeay Community Council on behalf of the residents and not by the residents themselves. This upset the residents who had paid money for the shares in the company.

In 1979 the company's articles were changed to enable the shares to be issued to residents so that they would have a direct say in the operation of the business of the company in farming lands purchased at Point McLeay.

In 1980 Ralkon made a submission to the Minister of Aboriginal Affairs which was conveyed to the Aboriginal Development Commission requesting that the land held by the Aboriginal Development Commission be transferred to it if necessary by purchase with adequate safeguards imposed to ensure that any public funding was properly protected. This transfer would enable long term development of the land to take place for the benefit of the aboriginal residents at Point McLeay. On the 23rd March 1981 the Aboriginal Development Commission without reference to Ralkon and the people of Point McLeay offered a lease of the land to the Point McLeay Community Council.

On the 28th March 1981 an election was held for the Point McLeay Community Council and after the election the Council reflected the views of the Point McLeay residents. At a number of Council meetings during March, April and May 1981 the Council resolved to reject all agreements between the previous Council and the Aboriginal Development Commission and requested that the farm land be transferred to Ralkon.

On the 29th May 1981 I visited Canberra with the Chairman of the Council to discuss this matter with Mr Perkins who stated there was nothing wrong with the company's Articles of Association and if the company could show that it could manage the farm the Aboriginal Development Commission would look to giving freehold title in the land. A majority of the Point McLeay community signed a letter to the Minister of Aboriginal Affairs on the 12th June 1981 requesting that the Department should not interfere further in the activities of the Point McLeay people. This letter also requested that the land be transferred to Ralkon .

On the 27th July 1981 following further persuasion from the Aboriginal Development Commission the Council signed a lease with the Aboriginal Development Commission which endeavoured to exclude Ralkon from any farming operation in respect of the property. The Directors of Ralkon believe that this decision was made against the wishes of the majority of Point McLeay residents and have sought to have the matter raised at various levels to ensure that the wishes of the majority of people are carried into effect.
The company has not caused any split amongst the people at Point McLeay. This split has been brought about by outsiders interfering in the affairs of the Point McLeay residents.

The Company has not unlawfully retained control of the farmlands at Point McLeay as on a number of occasions the community council have requested the Aboriginal Development Commission to transfer those lands to Ralkon.
Ralkon has managed the farming operation at a profit and has carried out proper accounting procedures, it has not refused an audit and it is not opposed to its account being audited.

The Directors of Ralkon who are all Aboriginals have been very happy with the management and assistance given by Mr Ian Hillock who has been the company manager for six years. Mr Hillock has, on a number of occasions, indicated that he would leave if so requested by the Directors but the Directors and shareholders have expressed their desire for him to stay and have been grateful for his continued support. The company is capable of managing the farm operation profitably and has sought to have the land transferred to it with appropriate controls to ensure the long term development of the land. The Aboriginal Development Commission has ignored the request of a majority of residents at Point McLeay to lease or transfer the land to Ralkon and has sought to impose its own will upon the people of Point McLeay.
Yours faithfully, S. RIGNEY Chairman Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd.

I have endeavoured as quickly as possible to condense the problem that confronts us at present. I have no doubts that there was some communication between Senator Haines and the Council. It is regrettable that whoever initiated what arose here last Thursday-I have my suspicions but I will not make them known here tonight-took that action. It is quite obvious that certain people want to cover things up and will oppose all the way along the line any public inquiry into the problems that exist there. I am concerned about that because it was said in the telegram which Senator Haines read out that I was causing problems and that the residents were disturbed at the way in which I had attacked officers in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. All I have said about officers in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is on the record. At this stage I do not back away from it. From the information in my possession I could say many more things, but I am not prepared to do so at this time.

As the Government will not agree to setting up a select committee, I make a humble request to the Senate that some means be found whereby the people on both sides of this problem and the officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs can get around the table and give evidence under oath so that we can get to the bottom of the problem. It goes back a long time. In 1975 the Labor Government paid for Bartlett's Farm, the property in question. That is on the record also. I repeat: I am sorry that I talked the people who came to see me initially out of making this matter public. They included Bill Koolmatrie and Andy Sumner. Both of those gentlemen are now dead, but three of those people are still alive. I have exercised the only means I know to get an inquiry into this problem. I only wish it could be held so that the whole matter could be laid to rest. As I said last Thursday and as Senator Peter Baume said, 'in emotional remarks', during debate on the Appropriation Bills, I wish the people who live down there could get together and farm that property for what it is worth. I am sure that the people there will be happy if only we, the legislators of this country-the people who have the means available to do something about it-can give them the assistance they deserve.

I hope that what I have said here tonight will be read by Senator Haines. As I said to her in the corridor after she spoke the other night, if she wants any further information I suggest that she talk to Bob Randall and get his views, not mine. She should get an independent point of view from him because he is on the opposite side of the fence. She should talk to Bill Nankivell who was the member for Mallee, which electorate encompasses this property. I have said before and I say again that Bill is a man for whom I have very great respect. He was the chairman of the consultative committee. I have letters on file from him, as I am sure Senator Peter Baume has-I know that he wrote to Senator Peter Baume -pointing out the problems that exist between the company, the Council and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. So it is not only my word. Two ex-Liberal members of parliament have taken up the cudgels for these people. Like me, they have been prepared to put their heads on the block and probably get them kicked in by people who are not fully conversant with the problems that exist. I am sure that, before an inquiry was set up, if Senator Peter Baume were to approach Bill Nankivell and Bob Randall and the people on the consultative committee-Mr Wayne Sanders, for instance, is a well respected farmer in the district down there-they would be prepared to come and talk to him. In future let us try to keep this out of the public arena. Let us have an inquiry into it and see if we cannot settle the problem for those very worthwhile people at Point McLeay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I think I should mention to Senator McLaren, through you, that I also received a telegram signed by Mr Rankin. I received it after the Senate rose the other night and I was not able to disclose its existence at that time. It may be advisable to seek to have it incorporated in Hansard. I think it is in the same words as the telegram received by Senator Haines. But rather than read it out, it might be appropriate to incorporate it. I think it adds nothing to what was already in the Hansard record. It would give Senator McLaren and others , in developing this issue, a chance to see what was sent to me. I seek leave to have the telegram incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
CAA 272= AST 93= J79=
Point McLeay Sub SA 407/389 3.30P
Senator Peter Baume
The Senate
Parliament House, Canberra

As Chairman of the Point McLeay Community Council and as a representative of the Point McLeay Aboriginal Community over the past twenty years I strongly deplore the political antics and ill informed grandstanding on Aboriginal matters by Senator McLaren in the Senate as reported in Hansard dated 17th November 1982. Senator McLarens views are biased towards a minority faction and certainly do not reflect the beliefs of my council or that of many Aboriginal people within this community. Senator McLarens unsubstantiated attacks on hardworking and longserving officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission which he so vigorously castigates are totally unwarranted and certainly devisive in our relationships with these Departments. The senators savour would be better channelled to more useful purposes from the Aboriginal Development Commission was a direct response to resolutions passed by my council seeking support in its endeavours to regain control and use of its lease holdings upon which Ralkon Agricutural Co. has continued to occupy in defiance of all previous attempts by my council to remove a small faction that occupies council lands to the detriment of the Council and the Aboriginal Community as a whole. I particularly bring to your notice that in 1974 I originated the concept of a farming project on council lands and as a result of this concept the council negotiated the purchase of Bartletts Farm through the then known commission (now A.D.C.) to compliment existing council farm lands. It was never intended that the farms management be other than as a sub-committee to the council and under the direct control of the council for the general benefit of the Point McLeay Aboriginal Community. The dispute between the Council and Ralkon Agricultural Co. is of many years standing and is currently the subject of litigation. TALK.START.PARA: —I responded to Mr Rankine and I will read the letter. It is very brief. It reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you for the telegram you sent to the Parliament where I received it on 25 November 1982. You may know that your telegram was raised in the Senate on the Adjournment Debate and I listened carefully to the remarks that were made.

You will know that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs have agreed that I should handle, at Ministerial level, all matters within government that relate to the Point McLeay Community Council and its relations with the Ralkon Agricultural Company. I therefore regard your telegram as an important input and will seek advice from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs on the matters which you have raised.
I remain,
Yours sincerely PETER BAUME

That went out on 29 November. I read that only to advise Senator McLaren of the action that I have taken for the reasons which he will know. The difficulty about this whole matter is that it all depends onto whom one looks as being a reliable correspondent and who is regarded as being unreliable. That involves value judgments and I think Senator McLaren has made that clear in what he has said today. It involves value judgments by the particular listener and that bedevils an appreciation of what is going on at Point McLeay. The issue really is that there are three Aboriginal groups in conflict one with the other. There is the Aboriginal Development Commission, which has the title to the piece of land in dispute; the Point McLeay Community Council; and the Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd, which is of but separate from the Point McLeay Community Council. There is no pleasure for us that that situation should exist but the three groups are locked in conflict and that conflict has become deep and bitter. It seems to me that the available judicial processes, through the courts, through the Ombudsman, through other kinds of existing processes of a judicial nature, are being used and that they represent the proper way to resolve the matter. I believe that it may be difficult to try to interpose non-Aboriginal white politicians into what is a difficult situation between three Aboriginal groups and to have us try to sit as judges-no matter how good our motives are-in a matter which is a conflict between three Aboriginal groups. It is really quite difficult in terms of our whole approach to self-determination and self- management. Also, I think it is fraught with danger as to whether it would resolve the problems.

Like Senator McLaren, I have been to Point McLeay. I have not been there nearly as often as he has but I was there in 1974 and again in 1981 when I was there as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. On that latter visit there was a meeting with the community and we discussed some of the issues involving the Ralkon Agricultural Co. and the community and some other matters. I had the occasion then to meet Mr Probyn and to meet Mr Hillock. I must say, just to put it on the record, that I formed a very positive view of Mr Probyn and the response of the community to him at that meeting. That is just an impression I gained at a meeting and, I must say, in the context of the meeting-this may have nothing to do with the management of the farm-I found Mr Hillock difficult to deal with. But I think he might have felt under some pressure or under attack and he responded in a rather prickly way at the meeting. That is as may be.

The fact is that the honourable senator has asked a number of questions in relation to where people live, whether they draw travelling allowance and so on. I undertake to try to get that information for him and let him know. As to whether there is a white bookkeeper, I shall find that information for him. But I must say that it is not unusual for Aboriginal communities to employ non- Aboriginal skills if that will help in the running of an enterprise.

Having said all that, I come back to the point that this is a very unfortunate situation. It is unfortunate for Aboriginal people and for Aboriginal advancement in that area. It is a conflict between three Aboriginal groups, and we who are non-Aboriginal, though we are concerned and worried, are outsiders looking in, not quite sure how to resolve it. With the best will in the world, I am not sure that the mechanism suggested by my senatorial colleague will be appropriate in the circumstances that I have outlined. Nevertheless, I shall read very carefully in Hansard what he said. Like him, I should like nothing more than to see the whole situation resolved to the satisfaction of all the parties.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were over 3,000 companies involved in the B. Maher tax avoidance scheme, as reported by the McCabe report.
(2) When did the Australian Taxation Office first have any knowledge of such a scheme and of any company involvement in it.
(3) Were prosecutions ever considered and if so why was no-one ever prosecuted.
(4) Who made the decision not to launch prosecutions.
(5) How many companies involved were actually investigated.
(6) Why was the investigation of the first current year profit company Stirling Court (1973) Pty Ltd allowed to lapse following B. Maher's declining to be interviewed in 1976.

(7) Why has the Taxation Office only interviewed three of the sixteen sham Directors apart from Donald Sears; in particular why did the Taxation Office not interview Judith Line whose company made purchases on April 1978 when she was living at the address notified and continued to do so until 1981.

(8) What action has the Taxation Office taken to investigate the operations of B. Maher Commercial Securities Ltd; Guide Securities Pty Ltd; Lloyd Errol Faint; John Patrick Donnelly; and Graham David Spence.
(9) Why did it take until November 1980, more than seven years after the beginning of the company dumpings, for legislation specifically intended to outlaw the schemes to be drawn up.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The McCabe-Lafranchi report disclosed information in respect of 923 Victorian companies which, it was asserted, indicated that the companies were ' dumped' and their taxation liability thereby avoided or evaded. It was also asserted that as many as 3,000 companies were involved in this kind of stripping arrangement.

The secrecy provisions of the income tax law prohibit the Commissioner of Taxation from commenting on the affairs of specific persons and consequently comment in respect of the alleged activities of B. Maher is not possible. However, the Commissioner has advised that his officers are looking into the affairs of over 4,000 companies of which some 3,500 have been identified as having been stripped of pre-tax profits before the enactment of the Crimes ( Taxation Offences) Act.

(2) As disclosed in the Treasurer's press release of 27 June 1982, which commented on the McCabe-Lafranchi report, a case of company stripping came to the attention of the Australian Taxation Office early in 1973.

(3) and (4) The Treasurer's Press release of 27 June 1982 indicated that the Australian Taxation Office referred a representative case to the Crown Law authorities for the institution of proceedings against persons associated with the stripping of the company. The role of the Crown Law authorities in such cases is to examine the matter and to determine whether a prosecution should be initiated. In relation to the various possible actions considered, the Crown Law advice was to the effect that there was insufficient evidence to establish a prima facie case or that no substantial benefit was likely to result from prosecution proceedings.

However, the Crown Law authorities later re-examined the relevant facts and law and the question of launching prosecutions is again under consideration. A Special Prosecutor is to be appointed for the purpose of taking action against those responsible for company stripping operations.

(5) Statistics are not readily available of the total number of companies that have been subjected to some degree of investigation action. However, at least 15 representative cases were investigated at length and steps were taken towards the possible institution of legal proceedings with a view to the recovery of unpaid tax and/or the prosecution of offences. The cases were representative of various factual situations involving companies with pre-tax profits being effectively stripped of all valuable assets and being left with tax liabilities unpaid. The Commissioner's practice in dealing with wide-spread scheme cases is to investigate selected cases of a representative kind so that the substantive issues can be resolved and the decisions used as precedents in other cases.

(6), (7) and (8) The secrecy provisions of that law prohibit the Commissioner from commenting on the affairs of the specific taxpayers mentioned or on specific actions taken regarding those affairs. However, the Commissioner has advised that, without agreeing that the assertions made are accurate, he is of the view that the actions outlined in reply to questions (3), (4) and (5) represent an adequate and proper response to the general situation.

(9) As indicated in the Treasurer's press release in May 1978 the Commissioner of Taxation brought to the Treasurer's attention the apparent need for criminal penalties to deal with practices which resulted in companies being denuded of assets and consequently being placed in a position of being unable to pay any taxation liability. The Australian Taxation Office put proposals to the Treasurer once it became aware that stripping of pre-taxed company profits was occurring on a wide scale.

During the period from May 1978 to November 1980 there was considerable reserve and caution within the Government as to whether the proposed criminal penalties were really appropriate and as a consequence further effort was devoted to establishing whether or not some method of coping with the problem could be found without resort to specific criminal penalties.

In deciding to present this legislation to the Parliament the Government also had the benefit of advice from its Taxation Advisory Committee and following presentation of the Bill many representations were received stating that the introduction of criminal penalties was an over-reaction on the Government's part . In the final analysis, the Government came to the conclusion that there was really no alternative but to enact specific criminal penalties.

The processes leading to the introduction of the legislation were, of necessity , detailed and time-consuming but, as was stated by the Treasurer, from his own point of view and that of the Government there was no avoidable delay.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the ease with which school children in the United States have been able to crack the codes of some of the most sophisticated and confidential computers in that country.
(2) Is it possible for people in Australia to perform the same feats of these American school children and gain access to information stored in computers used by the Minister's department.
(3) What security precautions have been taken to prevent such invasions of privacy.
(4) Does this ability to penetrate the secrecy of computers pose a grave security risk and leave hundreds of thousands of Australians open to blackmail and blatant invasion of privacy.
(5) Can the Minister give an assurance that confidential information related to his department files cannot be obtained by this method of 'plugging in' to computer systems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have noted that instances of unauthorised people in the United States gaining access to computers equipped with communications facilities via the use of acoustic couplers or remote dial-up facilities have been given wide publicity .

(2) It is not possible to access computers owned by the Treasury or the Australian Taxation Office in this way. Although the Australian Bureau of Statistics has some dial up facilities, access to information on these facilities is protected by the use of confidential access codes.
(3) (a) Treasury-Such invasions of privacy are not technically possible.

(b) Australian Taxation Office-Extensive security procedures exist. Their exact nature is itself secure. However the honourable senator is assured that the Commissioner of Taxation maintains a constant vigilance on the matter.
(c) Australian Bureau of Statistics-A number of precautions are taken including :
the progressive transfer of computer operations to a private network which uses only leased Telecom lines with no access from any public connection;
the location in secure premises of all terminals connected to ABS computers;
the use of confidential access codes; and
further protection of data files which might contain sensitive information through employment of an additional computer security system.
(4) No, so far as the computers operated by the Treasury, the Commissioner of Taxation and the Australian Statistician are concerned.

(5) The honourable senator is assured that every practical precaution is taken to secure the confidentiality of data held on computers operated by the Treasury , the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Australian Taxation Office. Due to the nature of the systems used and the precautions listed above, access cannot be gained to Taxation and Treasury computer files by the method of 'plugging' in to the computer system. So far as the Australian Bureau of Statistics is concerned, data are protected against unauthorised access to a degree appropriate to the risks and dangers involved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are Thai gemstone buyers who visit Australian gemfields for the sole purpose of buying the great bulk of Australian sapphires required to pay the Commonwealth Government any form of tax or royalty before they remove the sapphires to Thailand.
(2) Do those buyers dictate the prices they pay for such gemstones.
(3) Are Thai gem dealers required to pay duty on sapphires of Australian origin that they remove to Thailand for cutting and subsequent return to Australia for local sale.
(4) What is the ceiling price, as at September 1982, that the Thai gem buyers are offering Australian miners for their yield.
(5) Is the Australian sapphire the only gemstone that has depreciated in value in the past fifteen years.
(6) What weight in sapphires was removed from Australia by Thai gem buyers annually over the past ten years and what was the revenue to Australia from those sapphires over that period.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The New South Wales Government imposes a royalty of 4 per cent of ex-mine value on sapphire production in that State. The Queensland Government imposes a royalty of 5 per cent of the value of production of saphires in excess of $10, 000.
