QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 12 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the dingo presently classified as noxious under most State Acts, which obliges owners or occupiers of any land to destroy all wild dogs on such land.
(2) Are up to 100,000 dingo pelts being exported to the United States every year.
(3) Is the dingo threatened with extinction through the swamping of the gene pool for feral domestic dogs.
(4) Was the cost of dingo control in Australia in 1981 almost $7m.
(5) Does the dingo play an important part in the natural ecosystem by keeping down rabbits, feral cats, pigs and other pest populations.
(6) Have any studies been carried out to examine whether the dingo is an endangered species.
(7) Has the Government considered granting the dingo the legal status of a protected animal.
(8) Is the Government prepared to consider making the killing of the Australian dingo an offence under Commonwealth law.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) New South Wales-Dingoes are declared noxious. The owner or occupier is responsible to suppress and destroy (Pasture Protection Act). The Crown is not bound by the Act and dingoes are protected in the National Parks and Wildlife Service areas although there is some control where there are problems on adjoining land.
Queensland-Yes.

South Australia-The dingo is classified as a vertebrate pest but management policy requires eradication only in the southern (sheep) half of the State, and control only when numbers become excessive in northern (cattle) half of State.
Victoria-Yes. In the wild state the dingo is classed as vermin and land owners are obliged to destroy vermin on their land.

Western Australia-The dingo is classified as a declared animal. An obligation is placed on landholders to reduce their numbers and keep them under control. There is no requirement for total eradication. State policy dictates that control takes place only on and adjacent to pastoral sheep properties. Elsewhere little or no control is practised. Dingoes are not under threat from man's activities on vacant crown land and cattle properties in pastoral areas.
Tasmania-Dingoes do not occur in the State.

Northern Territory-Dingoes are protected in Arnhemland and on parks and reserves. They are classified as unprotected wildlife outside these areas. They are not classified as noxious and there is no obligation on landholders to destroy wild dogs.
Australian Capital Territory-The dingo is not classified as noxious.

(2) There is no evidence of any large scale export of dingo pelts. State and Territory Wildlife Authorities and Vermin Control Authorities consulted are not aware of such activity in their jurisdictions. The Australian Bureau of Statistics maintains statistics on the export of dingo pelts subsumed under the classification for dog hides and skins. It advises that for the 12 months ended June 1982 no exports were recorded under this classification.

The CSIRO advises that there is strong evidence from studies by the Division of Wildlife Research that there has been cross-breeding with domestic dogs in the wild in south-eastern Australia, but very little was detected from central Australia. The degree of cross-breeding is probably related to the closeness of human settlements and possibly to the continual exercise of control measures for dingoes. Whether cross-breeding will proceed to the extent that the dingo proper is bred out in any locality is unknown.
(4) A total cost of dingo control programs in Australia is not available.

(5) The CSIRO advises that there are indications from its studies that predation by dingoes may help keep down populations of some vertebrate pests at times. However, more research is required to decide the issue, especially the stage in the population fluctuations of prey when predation is most effective. Studies in central Australia indicated that dingoes may have kept rabbit and rodent numbers low for a year of so after those prey populations had declined during drought. In parts of Kosciusko National Park it is possible also that dingoes have kept feral pig numbers low. There are reports that in several parts of Australia feral pigs and wallabies have become noticeably more numerous after successful dingo baiting campaigns. CSIRO has not studied these situations to verify if this is true.

(6) Studies carried out by the CSIRO Division of Wildlife Research on the biology of dingoes indicate that few dingoes, if any, live in the very large areas in central Queensland, New South Wales and southern South Australia which are protected by the dingo fence. A study is underway to assess the status of dingoes in Victoria. Further inland and in northern Australia populations of dingoes fluctuate naturally, except when control measures are occasionally imposed. There is no indication that the dingo is an endangered species at present.

(7) The protection of wildlife is principally a matter for the State and Territory governments. Various State and Northern Territory governments have considered declaring the dingo a protected animal but have declined to do so. However, the animal is protected in most national parks and reserves and in the Australian Capital Territory.

(8) It is an offence to kill dingoes in the Australian Capital Territory, and in Uluru and Kakadu National Parks which are managed by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service for the Commonwealth Government.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Commonwealth Grants Commission: Tax Sharing Arrangements

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 September 1982 (Hansard, page 683) Senator Hamer asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the Commonwealth Grants Commission's inquiry into State tax sharing relativities.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The general review recently completed by the Commonwealth Grants Commission was the first comprehensive review of the relative distribution of general revenue assistance among the States to be published. Previous reviews have been conducted by the Commonwealth Treasury.

In terms of reference transmitted in June 1978, the Grants Commission was asked to consider the appropriateness of the relative distribution of States' tax sharing funds on the basis of the principle of fiscal equalisation. This principle seeks to ensure that tax sharing grants are distributed among States so as to enable each State to have the fiscal capacity to provide a standard level of services without having to impose taxes and charges appreciably different from those generally imposed by other States.
Following an extensive inquiry and two reports, the Grants Commission came to the view that a change was desirable in the then existing State tax sharing relativities.

The Commission's 1982 assessments were the subject of discussions between the Commonwealth and the States at a Premiers' Conference held on 24-25 June 1982. At this Conference, the Commonwealth and the States settled upon new tax sharing relativities based largely on the acceptance of the Commission's findings.

The relativities preferred by the Grants Commission were only modified in one respect. It was decided not to offset against their tax sharing grants any financial gain accruing to South Australia and Tasmania as a result of their hospital cost-sharing agreements with the Commonwealth. These States are entitled to keep any such gains until 1984-85 by virtue of Clause 7.1 of these agreements which stipulates that any above-average per capita cost-sharing grants paid to them are not to be offset by the Commonwealth against general revenue payments to those States. The Commission chose not to take into account the legal entitlement of these States, as it regarded it as a matter for decision between the Commonwealth and the States.

Another aspect of the new arrangements settled at the Premiers' Conference was the decision to phase in the relativities as modified over a period of three years in conjunction with a guarantee that no State would receive less than a specified real terms increase in its grants in any of these years. This took account of the fact that immediate implementation of the new relativities would have involved some States receiving significantly smaller grants. This was acknowledged by the Commission itself as constituting a case for phasing in any new relativities over three years.
The agreed relativities will apply in 1984-85 except to the extent that they turn out to be modified by the application of the real terms guarantee in that year.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1982 (Hansard, page 776) Senator Button asked the Acting Treasurer the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to the statement of the New South Wales Attorney-General in relation to tax evasion schemes investigated and uncovered by the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Office. I quote:
'We, that is, the New South Wales Government, have made many approaches over the years putting schemes to the Taxation Office which we thought were fraudulent. Nothing has happened'.

Is it true that nothing has happened? If so, why? Will the Minister undertake to supply to the Senate details of those approaches by the New South Wales Government by the next sitting day of the Senate?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that the allegation of inaction contained in the statement is inaccurate. The fact is that the Australian Taxation Office took the initiative in getting information from the Corporate Affairs Commission regarding the tax schemes and has been pursuing action under the taxation and other laws for a considerable time. The Commissioner also advised that taxation officers regularly use the facilities of the Corporate Affairs Commission and enjoy a good day-to-day working relationship with officers of the Commission. It is not possible for the Commissioner to disclose details of actions taken in specific cases on information obtained from his enquiries of the Corporate Affairs Commission.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1982 (Hansard, page 777) Senator Archer asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Frequently, Public Service addresses and telephone numbers which also appear in another section of the telephone book are cross-referenced , so that the only information given is 'refer to' or 'see item listed under' such and such. Will the Minister undertake to request Telecom Australia to examine this situation with a view to providing the full details of name, address and number of each listing, as frequently these important details are just as short as the referral?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, provided by the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

Market research has shown that the majority of customers are aware of the special Commonwealth, State and local government sections in the front of the directories. Many entries are lengthy and the repetition of the complete entry in the body of the directory instead of a cross-reference to the special section would be very costly. However, where the listing in the special section is short, then the telephone number and address details are generally also included in the main body of the directory. In the circumstances, Telecom would not wish to change the present arrangements.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Social Security Benefits and Taxation Rebates: De Facto Spouses

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1037) Senator Martin asked the Minister for Social Security, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister for Social Security aware of an anomaly between social security provisions and income tax provisions as they relate to de facto marriages, namely, that if a woman is living in a de facto relationship with a man his income is taken into account when she applies for unemployment benefit but because they are not married they are disqualified from consideration for the dependent spouse rebate?
Can he give a rationale for this? Will the Government give urgent attention to making the situation consistent?
Further to the response given by the Minister for Social Security I can advise :

The Treasurer is aware that there are different requirements in the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Social Services Act with regard to marital status but it is important to bear in mind that the relevant provisions of these two distinct Acts of Parliament have been designed to serve quite different purposes. The concessional rebate provisions of the income tax law, including the spouse rebate are designed to provide a measure of taxation relief for some of the family obligations and personal liabilities of taxpayers. My colleague the Minister for Social Security has already outlined the rationale behind the treatment of de facto spouses for the provisions of the Social Services Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1035) Senator Mulvihill asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, the following question without notice concerning the Abbott's Booby bird:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. By way of preface I refer to the disturbing evidence received in relation to Christmas Island and the inability of the Phosphate Commission to meet its share of the bargain in relation to booby bird habitat conservation. In view of the evidence that was received by Estimates Committee B, will the Minister undertake that upon the return of Mr McVeigh from the Cocos (Keeling) Islands expedition he will convey to him our concern in relation to the worsening of the position in view of the clear-cut environment program that was presented to the House earlier in the form of a report?
The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

During 1979 and 1980 a survey of the distribution and status of the Abbott's Booby on Christmas Island was conducted under the auspices of the British Phosphate Commissioners who were then responsible for the Island's mining operations. During the course of that survey and while the results were being appraised, a moratorium was placed on jungle clearing in all areas west of survey grid line 90,000E.

The results of the survey of the survey were assessed by an expert panel comprising Professor J. D. Ovington, Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, Professor J. M. Cullen of the Zoology Department, Monash University, Melbourne, and Dr J. B. Nelson of the Zoology Department, University of Aberdeen, the world's leading expert on the Abbott's Booby. The recommendations made by the expert panel were accepted by the Government and the Government's plans for the preservation of the Abbott's Booby were announced on 4 February 1982. Under management option 6 recommended by the expert panel, and accepted by the Government, some areas have been excluded from mining and revised mining plans are to be adopted in respect of other areas. Under this option, over 97 per cent of nesting sites recorded during the two year survey will be protected.

In addition, the Government decided that guidelines for jungle clearing and rehabilitation would be incorporated in territorial legislation. Those guidelines have been agreed between the parties and I am assured that they are being adhered to pending the preparation of appropriate legislation.

In their joint statement of 4 February 1982, the Ministers for Administrative Services and for Home Affairs and Environment emphasised that, coupled with restraints on mining, a monitoring program of the breeding success of Abbott's Booby would be implemented so that protection of the bird and the continuation of mining could be jointly reviewed on a continuing basis. A program has been developed by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) and agreed to by the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island (PMCI).
I need to correct Senator Mulvihill's misapprehension about the PMCI's contribution to the program. The PMCI has been and remains ready to meet its share of the bargain.
I am taking steps to ensure that the program commences as scheduled in March 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1194) Senator Colston asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning diesel excise and the Queensland Railways.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Prime Minister has received a number of representations from the Queensland Government and other State governments concerning, inter alia, the exclusion of State railways from the scope of the diesel fuel excise rebate scheme announced in the 1982-83 Budget.
The Prime Minister is replying to the Premiers' representations but, as such correspondence is of a confidential nature, it would be inappropriate for it to be publicly released.

As to the last part of the honourable senator's question, the Queensland Railways are now paying 6.155 cents per litre on excise on their diesel fuel. In that respect, they are treated the same as all other industries outside the scope of the rebate scheme announced in the Budget, including other transport such as road transport and coastal shipping.

The Government has withdrawn exempt status from some diesel users (including State railways) as one of a number of steps towards reducing its reliance for revenue on personal income tax through a modest broadening and deepening of the indirect tax base.
The total cost of the excise on diesel fuel to Queensland Railways will be a function of its future fuel usage, which the Commonwealth is not in a position to estimate.

Of the 6.155 cents per litre excise on motor spirit and distillate, 1 per cent per litre is a surcharge for 1982-83, the proceeds of which will be paid into a special trust fund to finance expenditure totalling $150m in 1982-83 on special road and urban transport projects under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. The Government sees the Program as a major initiative to bring about a lasting improvement in the road and transport system of the nation by 1988.

While the Government will monitor carefully the overall operation of the diesel excise arrangements, and has noted many representations to broaden the scope of the rebate, it recognises that any such moves would narrow the revenue base from which, among other things, the ABRD Program is to be funded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1346) Senator Tate asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the proposal announced in the Budget Speech to seek the release of funds from Statutory Reserve Deposits held by the Reserve Bank for home lending.

ANSWER.PARA: I undertook to seek the latest advice from the Treasurer who has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

I refer the honourable senator to my statement of 9 November 1982 in which I announced that the Government has decided to defer for the time being its request to the Reserve Bank to effect an SRD release of 1 per cent or some $ 300m.

This was done against the background of a significant increase in liquidity in the banking system since the Budget and an agreement by the major nationally- operating banks to extend the commitment made last March to lend an additional $400m of housing finance for a further 12 month period with effect from March 1983. Furthermore, these banks have indicated that, subject to a sufficient deposit intake and a sufficient number of eligible applicants, they would wish to increase this figure for the year commencing in March 1983 to $500m.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1429) Senator Crichton-Browne asked me the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I direct my question to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. Is it correct that, since the Commonwealth first proposed the establishment of a national crimes commission many months ago, no State or Territory has supported the proposal in its present form; the States and the Northern Territory have acknowledged that there is a serious problem of organised crime which ought to be tackled as a matter of priority; and both the Australian Police Ministers Council and the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General have approached the matter very positively and have, in accordance with their own initiative and the direction of the June Premiers Conference, undertaken detailed consideration of a number of options? Is it correct that at a joint meeting of the Australian Police Ministers Council and the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General on 24 September substantial progress was made and there was substantial consensus on the kind of structure which might be established to deal with the problems, and that at that meeting it was agreed that further work would be undertaken by officers prior to another joint meeting to finalise an agreement? Finally, is it correct that, notwithstanding the extensive process of consultation and negotiation which has been undertaken between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory in relation to a crimes commission, and notwithstanding a substantial measure of consensus, the Commonwealth proposes to proceed with the establishment of a Commonwealth crimes commission in the current session, having now unilaterally suspended further meaningful discussion with the States? Why has the Federal Government taken such action and what was the purpose of the negotiations and discussions in the first place? Were the States misled about the seriousness of these meetings?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

From the inception of its proposal for a National Crimes Commission, the Commonwealth has been very conscious of the desirability of involving the States and the Northern Territory in this national effort to combat organised crime. There has been a growing awareness on the part of the States and the Northern Territory of the problem represented by organised crime and the Commonwealth has welcomed the interest of the States and the Northern Territory and their participation in a series of discussions on this subject.

At a joint meeting of Police Ministers and Attorneys-General on 24 September 1982 the States put forward an alternative to the National Crimes Commission proposal of the Commonwealth. This alternative involved the establishment of ad hoc royal commissions, possibly co-ordinated by the Office of Special Commissions and the upgrading of the ABCI. Commonwealth Ministers agreed to give further consideration to this suggestion although making it clear that, for the time being, the Commonwealth maintained its position.

After giving serious consideration to this possible course, the Commonwealth concluded that in the interest of an effective fight against organised crime, the Commonwealth must continue with its proposal for a National Crimes Commission; at the same time it decided that provision should be made in the legislation for participation by the States and the Northern Territory in several possible modes. The National Crimes Commission Bill introduced on 21 October 1982 makes this provision. Discussions have continued with some States at officer level on the subject and the Government moved certain amendments to the Bill to accommodate particular concerns of some States to the Bill as introduced.

So far from unilaterally terminating discussions with the States, the Commonwealth is anxious to continue such discussions with a view to reaching appropriate arrangements for State participation in the fight against organised crime.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1930) Senator Lajovic asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister representing the Treasurer noted an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 October relating to the recent consumer price index figures and detailing certain costs but omitting such costs as electricity and so on? Could the Minister inform the Senate how these figures are arrived at, who decides which costs are included in the basket and whether the Australian Bureau of Statistics could publish a detailed analysis of all costs included in the calculation of the CPI and explain which are influenced by State or Federal government decisions?
The Treasurer has provided the following supplementary information in answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Australian Statistician is responsible for producing the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and for determining its composition and method of construction.

The Statistician recently published an up-dated version of a booklet 'A Guide to the Consumer Price Index' which describes how the CPI is constructed and includes details of the areas of expenditure included in the index, the relative weighting assigned to each in compiling the index, and information on the goods and services for which prices are collected. Copies of the Guide are available in the Parliamentary Library.

A large proportion of the items included in the CPI are influenced to some extent, directly or indirectly, by changes in State or Federal government taxes and charges. A number of government charges which are paid directly by consumers are represented in the index, among them: government-owned dwelling rents; electricity; postal and telephone charges; motor vehicle registration; and rail fares.

Because changes in prices from one period to another usually reflect a combination of various effects, such as changes in costs, profit margins and government taxes and charges, it is generally not possible to separate the different effects with any degree of accuracy. For this reason, the Australian Bureau of Statistics considers that it is not possible to quantify the overall impact of State or Federal government decisions upon the Consumer Price Index.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1982, (Hansard, page 1927) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that video cassettes sold in Australia do not require any classification as do films that go into the general theatre/cinema circuit in Australia? What can be done to prevent the purchase of these units by, say, children under 18 years of age?
The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commonwealth Government's powers under the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations are confined to the registration-or refusal of registration-of imported films and video cassettes. By arrangement with the various State governments, films and cassettes that are to be publicly exhibited are classified by the Commonwealth Film Censorship Board in accordance with State laws governing exhibition.

Controls over the advertising, display and sale of video cassettes for private use are the responsibility of the State governments. I might add that the general question of controls over the availability of video cassettes is currently being examined by Commonwealth and State Ministers with responsibility for censorship.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1927) Senator Bolkus asked Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, as the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the Minister to the fact that 1,386 cases of discrimination have been dealt with by Mr Al Grassby, the Commissioner for Community Relations, in just over a year and that all of these cases have been dealt with by persuasion and negotiation. I ask: Is the Minister aware of the disquiet in the community at the reports that the appointment of Mr Grassby will not be renewed when it expires at the end of this month? Is he aware also that over 200 letters have recently been sent to the Prime Minister from South Australia alone, calling for the extension of Mr Grassby's term because of his experience, knowledge and talent in this area? In view of the excellent record of Mr Grassby will the Government now renew his term?
The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

However, the Government believes that the nature of the position requires a change of occupant after several years so that new ideas can be injected into the work. Mr J. Long, a former Deputy Secretary in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, has been appointed to the office.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: South Africa: International Monetary Fund Loan

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2032) Senator Gietzelt asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning an International Monetary Fund loan to South Africa.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:
On 3 November 1982, the Executive Board of the International Monetary Fund ( IMF) approved a request by South Africa for two drawings totalling SDR1,000m from the Fund.

Prior to the approval of these drawings, the United Nations General Assembly had forwarded a resolution to the IMF stating that the drawing should not be permitted in the light of the policy of apartheid in South Africa. Australia abstained from the vote on this resolution.

The IMF is a specialised agency of the United Nations. Under the terms of its Relationship Agreement with the United Nations it is, and is required to function as, an independent international organisation, and accordingly is not bound to implement recommendations of the UN General Assembly.

The IMF considers requests for drawings in terms of its Articles of Agreement. The conditions of eligibility attaching to drawings from the IMF, as set down in the Articles, are essentially financial and economic in nature. The Articles do not provide for the withholding of a member's access to IMF resources for reasons of the domestic, social or political policies of the member.
In accordance with usual IMF procedure, the Executive Board's decision on the South African drawing was reached on a consensus basis. No vote was taken.

It is relevant to point that, although there is an Australian Executive Director on the Board, he also represents eight other countries apart from Australia. Thus, any views the Director may put forward on matters coming before the Board will not necessarily be those of the Australian Government.

The Australian Government remains firmly opposed to the system of apartheid and is ready to lend its support to internationally supported measures which will exert effective pressure on the South African regime to change its policies. In this regard, we appreciate the objections which many countries have to the provision of financial support to South Africa.

However, the Government respects the legal independence of international financial institutions, such as the IMF. The Government has no basis for objecting to the South African drawing given the terms of the Fund's Articles of Agreement and given the terms of the Fund's Relationship Agreement with the United Nations.
